description:
Been going here for 4 decades.   It used to be a great family restaurant with good take out and now is the mother of all dim sum restaurants on the mother of all dim sum streets in San Francisco.  The restaurant is undergoing slow repairs from a fire 2 years ago.

Why go here over others.  Well its sister restaurant Xiao  Long Bao just two doors down to the west is now more of the fresh noodle and dumpling kitchen while Clement Restaurant has transformed into the sweet pastry and exotic pastry bakery. You will see employees running back and forth between the two.

If there is a reason to come here beyond anything else it is for the curry bun.  Tired of the traditional pork bun or chicken bun?  You haven't lived until you've had their curry beef bun.  But just don't tell others.  They don't make that many and they flyboff the shelves fairly quickly.
author: Erik H.

description:
Normally go into the neighborhood for Dim Sum, but I was lured in by the ducks hanging in the widow. 
Got the 2 item lunch combo.
Noodles were a flavorless bunch of greasy worms.   Both my beef and pork selections were tough and dry.   The beef tasted like rehydrated jerky and the I think they were trying to finish off the half cooked noodles with the chafing trays.  We only ate half out of hunger, and then left our take home boxes on top of a sidewalk garbage receptacle, hoping a homeless person would appreciate it.
Maybe I should have went for the duck.
I'm going for Dim Sum now.
author: John W.

description:
Very bad customer service: They humiliated and yelled at me in front of other customers ... I had to retaliate!
I went here to buy Fortune Cookies for my company. When I first came in the store, I explicitly said I want "Fortune Cookies". I paid $125 with my credit card, but thinking that it's too much for 150 fortune cookies? and they told me to return in about 1 hour, 11AM. I was doing other errands and realized that I can't make it at 11AM, so I called them to let them know, but the lady on the other end of the phone said "no fortune cookies here" and hang up on me. I redialed just in case I got the wrong number and the same  lady answered and was adamant that they only have almond cookies, no fortune cookies and hung up. I did not have a chance to tell them that I'm coming 2 hours late. Me frustrated, I got to the store and they were giving me 150 sesame balls?! I explained my case nicely, but one lady badgered me and humiliated me in front of other customers in line. I yelled back and asked for a refund. I was being honest by paying ahead of time. They voided my transaction. I was shaking after that incident. I will never go to this place again, nor recommend it to anyone.
this is my first negative review of any place.
author: MLovely R.

description:
Solid food at insanely low prices- and I don't think they use MSG -next time I'll ask.

At noon on Sunday, Clement Street was busy with shoppers but without the throngs of people and chaos of Saturday market day.

While the dim sum place next door (Xiao Long Bao) looked tempting, the huge spread of entrees at Clement BBQ drew us in.

And if you're hungry (or hung over from Saturday night), one lunch box is enough to feed two people: They don't skimp and for $6 and change, it's a bargain.

Little one had the sweet & sour pork, fried rice & beef and scallions. For me, the fried rice noodles, jalapeño chicken wings & shrimp with vegetables.

I tasted the sweet/sour pork; it was tough and somewhat bland but he didn't complain.

But the spicy wings were delicious, lightly fried and savory with slices of jalapeño. The shrimp and vegetables, tasty with lots of crunchy shrimp and perfectly stir-fried zucchini, carrots and bok choy. 

Vegetarian dishes seemed limited to green beans unless the black mushroom dish was vegetarian?

I was taking too long to choose and I didn't want to hold up the line.

Service was perfunctory until I stuffed money into the tip jar and the ladies smiled and one heartily thanked me. 

(In my opinion, it's simply unethical not to tip, especially when you can see how hard the staff is working with prices kept low because of the competition).

Clement BBQ is take-out only (and cash only I think) plus conveniently located on a block with green grocers, to-go dim sum places and the city's best Asian supermarket (Richmond New May Wah).

Thumbs up!
author: Jennifer O.

description: Price dim sum that was just barely meh. My Good Luck Dim Sum shop was closed down the street so we gave this spot a try down the road. I am so sad I did. It was just meh. The har gow was filled with fatty fat and minuscule pork and the bbq pork buns were leaking from the buns...way too saucy and not nearly enough meat and filling. The meat that was there was pretty tasty but you had to search for it! Same issue with the shu mai... too much fat not enough meat...if you are in the area... find dim sum elsewhere. This spot seems to be better and serving Chinese fast food and stir fried items then dim sum. That's what I saw most of the customers eating at their small side tables.... I would not recommend.
author: Janet D.

description:
This is my favorite place for cheap, greasy, hefty portions, get the job DONE type of Chinese food. A true guilty pleasure. 

All day for $6.75, you get your choice of pork fried rice, chow mein, or steamed white rice. Along with that, you also get 2 sides, be it Mongolian beef, broccoli beef, sweet and sour pork, shrimp and veggies, various stir fry dishes, as well as egg rolls, whole fried shrimp, BBQ chicken, pork, or duck. 

They have a large selection of choices. 

Located in San Francisco's 2nd version of Chinatown here on Clement Street, the food is straightforward with no fuss. 

They accept debit or credit too

On a quick decision for lunch or early din din, I'll happily order takeout from here.
author: Ann S.

description: I personally did not try their dim sum, I got some of their honey bbq pork and it was as tasty as it can be. Make sure to get it with some fat!
author: Jie L.

description:
Zero stars. This review is for the BBQ portion of the restaurant. I did not get dim sum so I have nothing to report about that. 
I've avoided this place for many years, as the overwhelming smell of grease and dirt coupled with the dirty environment was just too much to take. Yes, in the past I've tried their cooked food, and while convenient, the grease was just too nasty. Last night, I was in a hurry and decided to pick up some BBQ pork (char sui) because I was pressed for time and this place was near my car and I figured what could go wrong with char sui? I was badly mistaken. 
Upon opening up the plastic box, I noticed that the char sui pieces were 70% fat. There were slivers of meat attached, but not much. As I was making char sui ramen, it was too late to change things so I made due with what I had. 
Upon eating a piece, my son immediately sensed that it tasted funny. He did finish two pieces before he asked to be excused. One guess as to where he went. My wife immediately tried a piece and concurred that it was probably spoiled or left out too long. I had them fish out the pieces and throw them away, and then preceded to throw out the rest of the box. 
Maybe this was an isolated incident, but I would just say that you can pretty much tell what type of place this is when you walk in and smell that smell. 
You've been warned.
author: Dom L.

description: Great take out place. Selection is great and food is fresh. You can get a plate with rice/noodles and 2 entrees for $6.50. I had the beef with bell peppers that was outstanding. Food is not too greasy.
author: Alan H.

description: I stopped in Clement BBQ when in the neighborhood for my monthly trip to Green Apple Books. The BBQ was delicious but it was the pork roll you MUST have. I try to avoid carbs but there was no guilt or regrets -- it was delicious. The sweet pork fills the fresh bread roll for a taste that you won't soon forget, and it's $2.00 or less. Best deal in SF.
author: Todd B.

description: The BEST coconut baked bun out there !!! The plac looks like any chinese place on clement ( not very appealing) but who cares ? Buy it, take it outside - enjoy it !!!
author: Victoria A.

description: I've been back many times since they reopened after the fire, and now serve dim sum out of the attached restaurant Xiao Long Bao next door.  The sizes of the bao buns have definitely gotten smaller, but they still are the cheapest and tastiest in the city in my opinion.  Still my favorite place to get dim sum!
author: Ms. E.

description:
Egg custard ($1.35 each) and BBQ buns ($1.60 each) were on point. Highly recommend them both. I judge all dim sum from the perspective of their ability to nail these two baked goods. They were great. 

Chinese food from the hot trays was mediocre but awesome portions on the combination plates.
author: Jazmin H.

description: This is the best place in Mccanna town to get him some at the current time a lot of places have closed up and don't look like they're going to reopen in good luck dim sum was closed for vacation that's also a great place for takeout
author: Sam S.

description: Filthy. I used to frequent this takeout place. This time I found a roach in my food. Not going there ever again.
author: Benny W.

description:
I went to Clement BBQ on 6/1 and bought a few deli items.  One of them was fried fish.  When I brought the food to my mom's.  The fried fish turned out to be a box of shrimp with veggies.  I was a bit disappointed, but thought maybe it was mixed up with another customer's order.  I took it home for dinner.  The shrimps tasted fine but the veggies were a bit sour.  I looked at the label on top of the box and it said sell by 5/31!  

I am so angry that they gave me the spoiled food.  The guy behind the counter looked very honest.  I guess looks can be deceiving like they say.  I was busy getting my money out and it was my fault for not keeping an eye on him.  I was too trusting.   I warn all customers to watch the deli guy's every move when buying food from this place.
author: Kisa L.

description:
I was just stopping by to get my Curry Beef Bun and Pork Congee fix and saw a pile of burnt crap on the curb and stood there shaking my head!  Cue the sad trombone....my comfort food world turned upside down on 3.18.16.  

I hope they come back sooner rather than later.  Thankfully no one was hurt from this horrible fire.  I'll never take this place for granted when they do re-open!  One of my fave places in SF for dim sum to go.  Tao Yuen in The Town is a close second for dim sum to go as well:  http://www.yelp.com/biz/tao-yuen-pastry-oakland?utm_source=ishare
author: David C.

description: Craving mon tao due to this grungy stomach bug I can't kick, scored some buns just before closing!
author: Tiffani L.

description:
What I ate: 2 entree combo plate
Visit date: January 2, 2016
First time? Yes.

Clement is an easy fix for hanger problems. Just pick from their large selection of warm entrees. I had the flat rice noodles with pork, lemon chicken, and tofu skin 'egg rolls'. Yum! Flat rice noodles are my favorite; Clement's flat rice noodles had just the right amount of salt so you can eat it alone or with an entree (like how you would eat rice). The lemon chicken is fried, kind of like a sweet and sour orange chicken. And what I'm calling tofu skin egg rolls were filled with glass noodles, cat ear mushrooms, and mixed veggies. It was like pancit wrapped in a tofu skin. 

Seating is limited. Bags are $0.10. Next time I'm coming for a whole BBQ slab.
author: Erin G.

description:
This place was my childhood regular place for cha siu bao - baked, steamed, it's all good. The only thing I hated was by mom sending me to order because she couldn't find parking and then me subsequently getting pushed around and cut in line by old Chinese ladies. 

Anyway, still great many years later!
author: Estella H.

description:
This is my all time favorite place for the steamed Char Siu Bao whether in Los Angeles or San Francisco.  Whenever in SF and I have a chance, I come here.  I used to buy these by the dozen, freeze them and savor them at home.

I am somewhat of a self proclaimed connoisseur of Char Siu Bao's.

Here's the disclaimer of my biases so you have the frame of reference to my review, proving you with the context for understanding my position...

I do prefer the White steamed BBQ pork bun over the brown baked BBQ pork buns, even with the honey glaze on top.

I do prefer with the White steamed variety that the char siu bao is not cracked on the top nor small, but is round to perfection, sort of like a "Size D cup sized Breast Implant" (or maybe an ample C),  like the ones here, as th Clement Restaurant are larger than the average bao you'll find or get, in in this case bigger is better too.

'nuff said!
author: Rick S.

description: I don't head to SF often, but EVERYTIME I'm near by. I visit this bakery. This time was a bust. I read they had a fire, but fire must have effected the future days. Although the BBQ buns are bigger than most, the visit lacked the meat it usually is encased in the sweetish soft buns. It's more much more bread than its itsy-bitsy meat filling, plus the meat inside was quiet hard. I was disappointed on this visit. Can anyone recommend a great Chinese BBQ pork bun in the Silicon Valley?
author: Chefs Daughter D.

description:
The good things about this place are:
- they have signs in English
- they're cheap
- fast

I did not particularly like the food I got here.
- Roast Pork: It was mushy and had no flavor. I could not eat it. Got 1lb of it, and it was like $10.
- Taro pastry puff: Had a weird flavor to it that I didn't like.
- Taro bun: I actually enjoyed this quite a bit. Would get again.
author: H. L.

description: This review is for the to-go lunch counter. Food is okay. My unhappiness is with the opaque prices and lack of price labeling on the above-head menu marquee. Different staff gives different food a la carte prices for the same food item. The staff's attitude is defensive and not at all friendly. I witnessed price gouging for a non-Chinese customer once. Lack of price labeling made it hard for the customer to ask for accounting.
author: Ling y.

description:
I am happy to see this place is reopened after their fire.

I went into this deli on Monday, late morning, to get some char sui (BBQ pork).  As I was ordering I saw something drop in front of me.  I look up and see a ton of (what I assume to be water) droplets on their ceiling dripping into the food on the steam table.

I immediately inform the cashier and she says, "I know, I know.  It is condensation caused by the steam table."  This could be possible but I would doubt it since the ceiling is pretty tall.  Even so, if it was condensation dripping back down, that is pretty nasty.

**TIP**  If you go in to order food, just look up and make sure nothing is dripping from the ceiling into the steam table food.  If it is clean and dry, you are good to go in ordering food.
author: Kevin D.

description:
They have my giant wheat bun with egg, myshroom, and meats. All the times I go, or my mom goes, you can find us hauling the giant wheat buns home. Try it! I've always had the white bread but you know, wheat is much healthier these days.

They also have your usual dimsum, but I'm not too fond of their dimsum, more of the bread. I did get some of their brown sugar thingy, not sure what you call it in English. 

Next door they have some good roast duck, chicken and lunch dishes. 2 items with rice will cost you less than 5.00. What a deal!!!!!!!
author: Eugenia W.

description:
My Go To spot for food to bring to family gatherings. Good food, cheap prices, but crappy service!!

BBQ pork buns: HUGE!!
Har Gau/Pork Shumai/Sharkfin Dumplings: YUM!!
Hot Dog Bun: Good some days, very dry other days. 
Fried Shrimp Rolls/Fried Shrimp Dumplings: OMG! So good! If weight wasn't an issue, I would be eating them everyday!!
Beef Curry Roll: So good, but it can get messy because it's too flaky!!
author: Darlene M.

description:
Love this simple, fast dimsum/bun place in my neighborhood.  such an easy concept to stop in and grab a snack.  buns are delicious and dim sums are decent.  love the "combination bun" which is a huge bun filled with chicken/cabbage, sausage, egg, bbq pork, and mushroom...a meal in one! 
nice sweet options and jook too!

service is fast and can be rude.  im used to it and i grew up coming here!
author: Linda T.

description: Absolutely horrible. The minute I ate steamed fish and peppers, and tofu, it tasted like they just coated it in No Flavor. It was a flavorless mush of dough and lumpy sadness. It reminded me of that image of the seafloor animal that looked like a large nosed smurf. I thought the line of people meant they had good taste, but crowds dont mean shit. After 2 angry spoonfuls, I dumped the rest in the trash.
author: Thomas L.

description:
My second stop on my dim sum hunt in Richmond.

*Note* I am basing all of my dim sum reviews on the following three items (as they are my favorites): Baked bbq pork bun, Har gao and Siu Mai.

Bao - I really disliked this bao. It had way too much breading. The filling was funky as well. Strips of pork mixed with onion strings and a strange flavor. MSG perhaps? I don't know, but it was not good.

Har gao - The filling in their har gao was actually pretty good. It was moist and had decent flavor. Unfortunately the outside of this item was really dry and not very good.

Siu mai - Much like the har gao, I liked the pork filling in this. It was moist and tasted decently. But again, the outside was really dry and did not get the job done.

-

I also tried the taro bbq turnover item. It was better than the other stuff I ordered here and had some nice crispy parts to it with some flavor. The pork strips they used went much better in this item than in the bao. However, this is not what I came here for.

Additionally, there is no seating in this place which, while not important, is always nice to have. There are definitely better dim sum places on clement street.
author: Mark O.

description:
Not just one place, but there different little shops to get your favorite Chinese BBQ, dim sum and combos. Order your dim sum in one shop, then go next door and order some roast duck and have a seat at the little counter. We got SO much great food, and at really low prices. 

Definitely feels authentic, from the ducks hanging in the front window to the roast whole pig parts hacked up on a rolling table next to the kitchen. The giant pork bao and shu mai were really good, and they even had jook rice porridge. Come hungry, because the portions are truly generous. We spent the whole afternoon in GG Park trying to walk off lunch.
author: Tom M.

description:
Still delish!  I remember getting 3 hau gow for $1.25 and now it is up to $1.75!  Still worth it though.  The chive dumpling and shrimp rolls are also so good.  

The service is fast so you get food fast even if there is a line! 

I still have yet to find better tasting dim sum anywhere else in the US that I have visited...
author: Lydia K.

description:
Came by to order baked goods the other day. 

Ordered half a dozen baked BBQ Pork Buns as my favorite Lung Fung is out on vacation until mid-November.

There was a ~10 minute wait as they still needed to be baked.

In the interim, ordered an egg tart and it was excellent! The filling was tasty and the pastry crust was fluffy and crunchy!

They accept credit cards more than $10 and offer a box more than 7 buns.
author: Derek S.

description:
Dimsum:
-Water chestnut cake, basically just sweet yellow jelly with sweet pieces of water chestnut, predictably done
-Beef turnover puff, standard
-BBQ pork bun, giant freakin bun, but sauce to meat ratio was too high, and there were small pieces of bone in the mix

Service:
-Meaner than usual counter lady, yelled at me when I gave her a penny when she apparently asked for a dime in chinese, made me feel bad about my chinese-translations-for-monetary-units illiteracy in a line-ful of old asians
author: Tian Q.

description: Best egg tart ever!!! The shell is really crispy and soft, and it's the real Portugal/Macau style!!! I miss it so much!! I had tons of the egg tarts that have the hard shell:( also! The egg part is really creamy and yummy too!! Love it! I'll come back!
author: Timtim H.

description:
Walked here from my friend's apartment at around 11:30 on Sunday - there was a line of about 10 Chinese old folk which was a good sign that we were in the right place :) 

I got like 2000 calories worth of Chinese buns/baos/pastries for $11. That included: 
3X xian2 shui3 jiao3 (salty dumplings)
3X cun1 juan3 (veggie spring rolls)
2X nuo4 mi3 ji1 (lotus-wrapped rice)
1X cha1 shao1 su1 (cha-shu pastry)
1X mysterious chicken and onion pastry

And they weren't like, regular sized like at dim sum restaurants. Everything was at least double the size I expected them to be! Fantastic!!

A lot of the deep fried things were super oily, but um, what do you expect? I also tried the baked and steamed cha shao buns, the winner of which is the steamed cha shao bao! Get that one. Skip the other two types.

I'd recommend coming with a Chinese speaker, or at least learning the names of all the things you like to eat, so that when you get pushed to the front of the line and yelled at to make your order you're prepared.
author: Jenn W.

description: Clement St BBQ is open again! Shopped there this morning June 10, 2016. The "Dim Sum to Go" is temporarily operating within the "BBQ" side. Glad to see them back in business.
author: Jordan L.

description:
This is a takeout dim sum place. Got some time to spare in the morning, just wanted something quick to eat with mom before we drive out. I got their beef rice roll for $3, and 3 pieces for $2 deal. I had the salty fried triangle, fried taro with meet, and a turnip cake. I was very disappointed cause these items like essentially my favorite and is a hit in dim sums.

I wanted shrimp rice rolls, but the lady before me took the last two... ARGGG LADY!
My beef rice roll was not entirely cooked, the meat was still pink and the noodles were soggy. The turnip cake was bland and really doughy. The taro fried thing was kinda stale... but i did enjoy the salty fried triangle very much! the fried layer was just right and not overly thick, and the meat inside was yummy! Service, don't expect too much as it's a go in, order, pay and leave kinda deal. they want you in and out, so don't be offended if there's lack in customer service. 

Will i go back? not intentionally, but if I'm in the neighborhood, i might pick up some salty fried triangles :)
author: Cindy C.

description:
I was in the Inner Richmond, and asked someone where to go for some good cheap Dim Sum.  They recommended this place, and it REALLY delivered.  Every single thing I tried was great; my favorite was the chives / celery / shrimp dumplings, but the shu mai was very good, as was the egg custard desserts.  

You get more food than you can eat for around $8 a la carte.  I'll be back for sure.
author: Zachary R.

description:
Clement Dim Sum
SF: Inner Richmond
Saturday March 3, 2012
Four Stars

[SF#3]

You cannot find good dim sum anywhere in San Diego.  However in San Francisco, I can just walk down street and find 10 decent looking places on one street.  I ventured into Clement  Street Dim Sum (with the Yellow Sign and red lettering).  The Asian lady in front of me order 3 dozen Ha Gow and 3 Dozen Shumai, I knew this place was going to be delicious.  I ordered 2 orders of Shrimp Ha Gow, Pork Shumai, and Pork Xao Lon Bao.  I also order 4 Baked Cha Siu Baos, which I had been craving for such a long time.  To Go Dim Sum was the perfect pre-brunch snack for under $15.

Cash Only!
author: Leonard L.

description: My favorite go to place for steamed pork buns, pastries and sesame balls on my way out of the city.  The original place burned down, but it is up and running next door which I was excited to hear about.   All the items are tasty and fresh and just like I remembered as a young kid.  Parking can be a nightmare since it is a neighborhood place especially on the weekends so park away from Clement Street is encouraged.  If you are a person who orders large quantities of pork buns and are taking them home to be frozen you can order ahead.  Recommend that you get them cold so they are easier to transport and freezer ready.
author: Christine G.

description: This won't be the cleanest restaurant you'll ever visit but who cares ... seeing all my childhood grinds and what I grew up on when living in Hawaii excited me beyond control.  Char siu baos, pork hash, jook porridge, roast duck, sweet sour pork and chow fun was our entire order. It came in a humungous portion, cost less than $20 for everything and fed the both of us.  This was a great find when venturing out to Clement Street in San Francisco, an incredible area with blocks and blocks of Chinese Restaurants serving dim sum, to choose from.
author: Kelly P.

description:
Big, fluffy, tasty buns. Decent variety of dim sum items. Comforting rice porridge with Chinese donuts. All at pretty low prices. 

Just be ready with your order and your cash because there is no dawdling! 

I haven't been to the place next door which does Panda Express-like service with the combination boxes.
author: K. S.

description:
When I saw the prices here - bbq pork buns ($1.25) , coconut buns ($1), egg custard ($1) - I was just expecting the small 3 buns on a dimsum plate. But upon closer inspection of the wares in the case I saw they were huge. In the end I just got one of each. Yes, lunch of all of the above for just $3.25 and I couldn't even finish the coconut bun. I had the other half later in the afternoon.

The bbq pork bun was really excellent. The bbq pork was moist and tender, sweet and offset by the onions in the mix. I've never had bbq pork like that before. Really liked the sweet & savory combination. Did I mention how big the bun was?

The coconut bun was also excellent. Like half a small loaf pan sized with fluffy bread and an almond (?) coconut filling. I love coconut so it was kinda a given I would like this bun but I didn't think I would like it this much!

Egg custard was okay. I'm going to stick to Golden Gate Bakery. The pastry was flaky but a little underdone - could have baked a bit longer and browner. Very pale.
author: Jean K.

description: Stopped by because of the reviews.... Pretty disappointed after tasting the food though. Ordered a 2 item rice place (Sweet & Sour Pork and some kind've fish).... Flavor just wasn't there and the pork definitely didn't taste like pork. Texture was like it had been sitting out for awhile..... Maybe it was just one of those days for the cook..... Unfortunately it's definitely one of those days for my stomach now.....
author: Javier C.

description:
This was our first experience eating dim sum. We waited about 5 minutes before they got to us. We picked several items to eat from different cases. All were very tasty! 

The onion cake was really yummy and still warm when I ate it. The combination bun was my favorite item I tried. With some egg and mushroom, along with meats, in a warm & fluffy bread like bun. So unique and really good. My husband and I were stuffed, and spent less than $9 for our food. I did not try the sesame roll, but it looked delicious. 

They got 4 stars only because we have know idea what it SHOULD taste like. But, we really enjoyed it!
author: Laura G.

description:
The food here has been consistently good. The pork buns are huge. The shui mai and the hargow are tender and flavorful. I've brought a couple friends and my fiancee here and they've all been blown away with how much food you can get for only like $10. The food is cheap, it's tasty and that's all you really need to know.

The service is pretty fast, a line out the door will still see you served in about 10 minutes. They may not be the friendliest bunch, but I've grown used to this as I often crave Chinese food and Dim Sum.

Parking is generally pretty easy to find, but you still have to pay unless you don't mind parking several blocks away and walking.

There's really not much seating, so grab what you ordered and go find a park somewhere to enjoy your food. Get here earlier in the day! They start running out of stuff towards closing.
author: Marie H.

description: Tried their roasted the 1st time, pretty tasty without fatty, greasy feelng.  Will pre order their roast whole  baby pig next time.
author: Kiana L.

description:
Fast and cheap dim sum. 

The beef rice noodle and har gow are way too thick for me. The beef in the rice noodle was sausage like and off putting. Everything was lukewarm and Shu Mai was like a dry meatball. The steamed BBQ pork bun didn't have enough filling. Sesame balls were okay. 

Like I said, fast and cheap. Good Luck Dim Sum has much better quality though.
author: Pearl L.

description:
I'm here for the Baked BBQ pork buns and the Pineapple buns,  best place for these on Clement...

If you want other dim sum like haw gow and siu mai, then go to Good Luck Dim Sum one block away where I think that stuff is better there...

Big, fluffy, not chinsey buns... the best... and so reasonably priced (cheap) too...

We always come here and Good Luck for takeout...
author: Lawrence L.

description: Mar 18, 2016, Fire at location.  Don't know when it will be back in service.  Going to miss their BBQ Buns.
author: Eric C.

description:
Review for the BBQ pork buns only.

I love bbq pork from the Chinese delis.  Put in a baked bun and you have a delicious treat times two.  

A friend recommended that I check out the bbq pork buns at Clement Bakery.  On a Saturday afternoon, I got into the waiting line that started from the back of the store. While waiting, I was able to see that they carry many types of dim sum, pastry/bakery items and porridge as well.  Then my eyes gravitated to the tray of bbq pork buns behind the counter. As my turn neared, the six remaining buns were sold.  Oh no!  My turn came and I asked if they had more buns and the server said it'll be out in five minutes. True to her word, the next tray of buns came out of the kitchen. Yes!

The bbq pork buns ($1.25) are on larger size compared to others that I've had.  The bun had a nice toasty texture.  The filling consisted of not overly large bbq pork pieces that were tender and some pieces of onion in a sauce that was not overly sweet.

Overall, very good bbq pork bun that has made my list.
author: Al L.

description:
So good. Shrimp rolls are outta this world. The Chinese donut is very hearty. I've eaten it by itself but can't wait to have it with some jook. My boyfriend loves getting the beef shumai. He no longer settles for the pork and shrimp one any longer. 

Really take out only. I'm always here around 2-3 and there's always a line but moves super fast.
author: Z C.

description:
Stop #2 on my quest for bbq pork bun greatness...

I got the baked bbq pork bun at Clement Restaurant for $1.25 and was really impressed with the size and flavor of this bun. Toasty outside, sweet chunks of pork and surprisingly good chunks of onion to add a little more flavor. The sauce is a little on the sweet side, and the pork is not stringy whatsoever. I learned that I prefer my buns baked, not steamed (though each has its benefits). The only thing I noticed is that the workers aren't too friendly, but since this is a stop-and-go sort of place I'll overlook it.

4.5/5 stars!
author: Liz G.

description: Came here today because Good Luck Dim Sum is on vacation. So glad I gave this place a chance because it might just be my new go to place for dim sum. Their pork siu mai is smaller and not as good as Good Luck but it is not bad at all. Their fried taro dumpling and fried pork dumpling tastes awesome. Their egg tart was also good. I am definitely coming back to try everything else! Oh, their health score is 92, which really isn't bad for a Chinese restaurant. Me likee.
author: N N.

description: This is the absolutely best place to buy Lo Po Beng in the entire City!  We used to go to Eastern for over thirty years before discovering this place! Actually my Mother found it after sampling every bakery in the City! We buy dozens to bring to friends and family! This is also known as winter melon cake!!
author: Troy F.

description:
Came here at the tail end of dimsum on a Sunday, and was able to grab the last few pieces of shumai and other dimsum goods that they had. I liked that they accepted CC's (albeit a minimum of $10), and the prices were standard... turnip cake was pretty good, as was the shumai... the scallion pancakes were way too flour-y.

Worth returning to try some of their other stuff though.
author: Diana K.

description:
Wow this place knows how to redeem itself. Even though my first couple visits practically tarnished my relationship to this place, I could never stay away too long because its my bf's childhood favorites for pineapple buns. We came back here recently to get some buns and I couldn't help myself but to order ha gow again, risking the chance for disappointment if its cold. 

The line stretched to the back and we waited as they efficiently served customers. It was our turn in just 5 minutes and those ladies really have a good memory of people ordering various items. We ordered pineapple bun, scallion with dried pork (MUST MUST TRY!), ha gow, and cocktail bun. We paid and walked our way back to my VIP parking spot just outside. We dove right in and the smell of all the buns just take over. The ha gow was so steamy and warm in my hands that I inhaled it. The pork bun and the scallion bun is a must try! The smell of the scallion itself draws out that warm feeling inside me as if I've been starving for days and its the first thing I see. For me, its nostalgic. I remember my dad bringing buns home on Sunday mornings and we would enjoy it together. 

You must come here! For me its a hit or miss but I'll risk the miss any day just for that chance to eat the buns!
author: Connie C.

description:
Big puffy ridiculously delicious baos in all flavors and varieties! The chao shao buns here are amazing, both steamed and baked! Do yourself a favor and get one of each. Perfect meat to bread ratio, generous amounts of both: a beautifully rotund pocket of heaven handed to you all warm and toasty and comforting.

The pineapple buns are also to die for. Irresistably golden crunchy topping gently embracing a sweet soft roll. Ahhhhh! And the size of my face and a half! Oh I could cuddle it to my cheeks and breathe the cozy scent of freshly baked bread forever. 

I've been to a lot of Chinese bakeries, near, far, around the world, but this little gem in the Richmond is one of the best I've ever visited. There's a lot of competition in the area, but this is only place around you need bother with. So cheap! So good! I'm so hungry...
author: Carol C.

description: I hope they both open soon again from the fire. Kinda crowded w/customer bunched up in that one store. The food is still good & reasonable. Thelma & Louise still working behind the bake goods counter. Their quantity pricing is smart, so to move their goods while keeping prices reasonable. And they taste good to start with. Their pineapple bun, cocktail bun goes great w/ my coffee. I've ordered pineapple bun w/my coffee all over the bay area & they're by far the best in how well baked they are w/that perfect flavored crust on the top. I can't have any deep fried food but see many people ordering it. Nice selection of Chinese BBQ's hanging on the display. Looks & smells good. Due to dietary reasons against oil I don't order it. I just step in & take a whiff of all the aromas. Torture. The selection of stir fry dishes are good not too greasy like some of the other similar Chinese places nearby. The pool of oil @ the bottom of the pan is a turn off for me. But here its just the right amount. Their daily special is the 2 items behind the buffet counter w/rice or noodles. A dandy lunch kept below $10. Hang in there W. I know the process to rebuild is nail biting but when you'll open again. it'll be better than before.
author: Stevie C.

description: This review is only for their sweet sticky rice with peanuts. It's the best I've ever had.  The rice was perfectly cooked and unlike others with mostly rice, this one had lots of goodies inside including sausage, duck yolk, pork and lots of peanuts.  Delicious!  It was only 2.60 and had I known how good it was, I would have purchased a dozen. They are good after being frozen too.  I came here by accident and thought it was a different place.  Glad I made the mistake!
author: Lorissa W.

description: This is my go to place for the best BBQ baked pork buns in SF. Does anyone think the recipe/taste changed after the fire?
author: Sue D.

description:
I picked up a lot of different breads here, but the two that stood out was the taro bun and the coconut bun. They both were breads swirled with filling and baked in paper liners. The taro was a smooth paste and was absolutely delicious! The coconut one was just as good, with sweet coconut flakes. YUM!!

Six pieces of bread came out to $6.45
author: Leslie P.

description:
The woman took me to pick up more dim sum here after a negative experience across the street. The prices are very reasonable and the portions are pretty substantial. The pork potstickers and gao choi gaos were crispy and tasted pretty good while hot and were still delicious after reheating them later that night. The bakery seemed clean and warm unlike the dim sum place across the street which felt dirty and cold.

I'd like to come back to try their cha siu bao, siu mai, and ha gao next time I'm in the neighborhood to get a better idea of how this place really stacks up.
author: Brian E.

description:
Here's another 2.5 star review.  This dim sum shop would be awesome if not for one thing ... MSG !!   

I finally decided to try this place after reading a Yelp friend's glowing review some time ago.  I was out running some errands and decided to drop in just for a few things for a late breakfast.  My small order consisted of three har gows, three pot stickers and one chicken combination bun.  It's quite a bit of food to have for breakfast, but I'm just glad I had a big can of Monster energy (not sold here) to wash it all down with.

It hit me with that very first bite into the potsticker.  The MSG that is.  I'm pretty sensitive to the stuff and I felt the sting on the tip of my tongue as soon as I tasted the filling.  They must use a lot of it because it was very noticeable in all three items I purchased.

The potstickers are plump and the skin is soft and oily.  Inside you'll find a stinging mixture of ground pork, chopped cabbage and ginger.  I'll bet this would have been tastier without the MSG.  The har gow had a stinging mixture of firm pieces of rock shrimp, some tapioca starch and solid cubes of bamboo shoot.  I liked the skin which was thin and very chewy almost like chewing gum.

I usually order chicken combination buns over regular chicken buns.  Most places give you chicken, Chinese sausage, hard boiled egg and a piece of shiitake mushroom.  The tongue-stinging mixture offered in Clement's version features chopped cabbage that is still crunchy instead of the mushroom.  In addition there's a piece of chewy BBQ pork inside as well.  Here is how it looked dissected (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MKGPb57KYoj11x0t7r5HGw?select=DmiUDqQnSH5b8Y76NIxB2A).  I liked the bun itself which had nice texture and good flavor, but damn the MSG which ruined the entire product.

I don't think I'll return for any of their savory items anymore, but I might try some of their sweeter pastries sometime in the future.  Friendly service.  The ladies speak both Chinese and English.  Carry bottled water with you if you're sensitive to MSG.  You'll need about three liters of it to wash away that sting from your tongue!
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: Amazing dim sums. Good price and fast service.  The dim sums had plenty of meat and veggies, unlike those we have in south Florida which were filled with starch and soaked in oil. Bring cash, you can get enough for two person with less than ten dollars. The egg custards were to die for as well.
author: Min J.

description:
This maybe my "go to" place for steamed cha siu bao which I just adore.

Why?

1. Large buns

2. Bao has a swirling thing on top.  Looks like a kewpie doll head, but in bread.

3. The bao is closed up and not burst open exposing the meat.  I don't like that.

4. Takes 5-7 minutes to steam from refrigerator to table.

5. Tastes really good.

6. The meat is moist, good quantity, natural colored

7. The bao has great texture. It doesn't get starchy while chewing it.

8. Best one I've had  in San Francisco
author: Rebecca B.

description:
Such a tasty bakery for super cheap! I always make sure to stock up on baked goodies when I'm in the area. It gets crowded though! I've found that there is no true "line." At times, you need to speak up with your order if you want to fight out all the intense asian ladies!

Lai wong bao's (custard buns) are my favorite. DROOL.
author: Michele P.

description: Probably one of the better dim sum places I've been to. I wouldn't call it a restaurant even though there are 2 2-seater tables. It's more like a bakery and order things to go. There was a long line when we passed by it, and still a long line when we decided to go in and buy some things. Good thing we just had lunch or we would have bought everything LOL. Got 2 bbq steam buns, 2 baked bbq buns, chinese sausage roll, 2 egg custards, and 2 egg puffs. We did take them home and ate for dinner... and wow they are all very good, without exception. Our favorite though was the baked bbq bun!! Fresh ingredients, quality taste, and super cheap. They had more items like shu mai and we'll need to try those next time. Oh and cash only.. but $10 should feed a whole family LOL it's so cheap!
author: Vol T.

description: I still love this place.  A nice variety of hot food and steamy goodies to get on the way to work.  I came in last week to get 30 pieces of their Shrimp & Cilantro fried egg rolls to bring to the office for an office mate farewell.  They were a hit (except for the vegetarians anyway).  I was really trying patiently to wait for their baked Chicken stuffed pastry that was not out yet, but it was taking too long.  Oh well.  Next time!
author: Emy B.

description:
New to neighborhood and stepped out for a late lunch. Walked up and down Clement to get a "lay of the land" and Clement BBQ seemed to fit the bill at the moment. Excited to see that a 2 item combo plate was only $5.25! After ordering beef stew, Chinese broccoli and chow mein, I happily sat down at make shift counter space to eat. 

Unfortunately the food was all luke warm if not almost room temp! Also not a ton of flavor. Well there are always plenty of other options...
author: Christopher W.

description:
I looove this bakery. Not only for the baked goods (I'm totally addicted to pastries), but the dim sum is actually pretty good too!

My all-time favorite item. Prepare yourself....
BAKED EGG CUSTARD BUN. Way better than the common steamed nai won bao, this has a baked-crispy-amazingfulness-texture that you've got to try. It has the eggy custard middle, the fluffy bread outer, and the topping is a coconutty-crumbly DREAM. Not shaved coconut or anything, but you can get that hint of flavor. Try it. I think they have pork bun style / char sui bao of this too.

Spicy shrimp dumplings are also the go-to.
author: Tay R.

description:
THE BEST dim sum spot on Clement.  Those purple taro root pastries are on my top-five list of all-time-absolute favorite treats.  Although I haven't yet tried the meal/savory section, I'll be damned if it doesn't look fresh and healthy and scrumptious (and I shall report back on its worth when I do finally get in here for a meal).  
Expectations have been met repeatedly, and over a good year's worth of patronage.

Eat here!
author: Rachel S.

description:
Best baked BBQ Char Siu Bao (pork buns) ever! My friend introduced me to this place and now that I live down the street I am addicted. The buns are only $1 and deliciously filling. So big and yummy.

You can also go next door and get mountains of chow mein and fried rice for under $3 a pound.

Try the pork buns and you'll never turn back!!!!
author: Rachel G.

description:
We've been coming here for 25 years and it is our gold standard for dim sum everywhere on the planet. No other place quite measures up!  Char siu bao is amazing - so much lucious pork filling. Ha gow is perfect, curried beef turnovers, dried shrimp noodles, tripe, it's all best ever.  Truthfully, I've had so much dim sum, U.S., Europe, Hong Kong... Nothing quite as good and fresh. My favorites are the baked pork buns. Even three days old reheated for breakfast, they're better than the competition. 

The restaurant is okay, but I usually don't bother cuz I'm all about the buns. My daughter, as a little kid, developed a passion for their chicken feet and ha gow and still waxes poetic from another state where the dim sum is merely okay. 

I'm living in Berkeley half time and India half time. I'll still make a beeline for Clement Street as soon as I hit the States. It's probably my favorite food ever, anywhere!
author: Joy S.

description: This place is insane. No one has good food unlike these folks. Took my work break here and this place had the greatest pork buns know to the Asian Tongue.  If you are here please stop by
author: Michael W.

description: This place is 3 different establishments in one. I've only tried the bakery section, the far right side storefront. We always get the sweet egg yolk bun. It's kinda like a sweet custard bun that they call Lau saa bao translated to golden sand bun. Sooo good! We usually get an order of the beef pancake and a six pack of the sweet egg yolk that we eat half right away and save the rest for later.
author: T L.

description:
I watched Olympic game the other night.
About the NBC sportscaster Bob Costas.
Why he looks always like ... "sorry",  or just made a mistake, or "stunned" or a kid who just peed in pants, or the face after premature-ejaculation.
Especially his eyes, premature-ejaculation-eyes.

I always make the face, premature-ejaculation-face, when I had a Cheap Bad Chinese take out.
Cheap Chinese Take Out Food is the food to keep all American going still in the economy we have now. The food is necessary for all of us because the price.
So, we all know and expecting that it maybe pretty bad and will regret eating it.
But most Cheap Chinese are OK, because they use lots of sugar and msg to manipulate flavor to fit American taste.

we all So fxxxed.

There is nothing you can do when you got a Cheap-Bad Chinese Take Out.
Cheap-Chinese-Shit.
You just make the face, that's all.

About the Clement Restaurant.
The place divided by 2.
Bakery section for left and Chinese take out for right.
I came the Chinese take out section for 1st time.
The C.C.F (Cheap Chinese Food) was REALLY GOOD.
The sticky rice so good.
I'd say The Most Decent Cheap Chinese Take out.
Everything on the counter decently prepared and cooked nicely.

The place is not really look attractive, pleasing or appealing to the senses on the Clement Street. It's kind of hidden, but It looks clean enough. it's not super clean but it's not super-bad like Tu Lan-Bad either.
The food satisfied me very well.
I liked it.
I made a stunning face, full-ejaculation-face.
I'll be back.
author: Nobu K.

description:
The curry beef turnovers here are incredible.
The meat-pie filling has this rich and full-on-flavor.
How do they make them so delicate?
I also pounded-down one of their baked char-siu baus.
The pork filling is really savory/umami.
Beef and pork on-the-go. 
Not bad for today's hump-day.
...definitely a permanent Yelp bookmark!
author: Derek N.

description: If you buy food here you're playing with your life. Think bloody fried chicken wings. When a resturant smells worse than the fish market next door be afraid.
author: Justin S.

description: Called the manager (number given by employee) on Friday 4/15 to ask if I needed to special order 5 dozen steamed and baked pork buns and 2 dozen chicken buns.  Was told to go to 625 next door, not 621.  Didn't ask me for my name or phone number but was asked what time I would be by.  Fast forward to Saturday 4/16, I see a sign on the window that the place is closed due to a fire.  Went next door to 625 and asked if they had baked pork buns or chicken buns.  Lady behind the counter said they only had curry chicken buns.  Steamed buns looked smaller,  sadly and irritated,  I left and desperately called all my dim sum eating friends to suggest another place on Clement.   Around 3 oçlock, I received a phone call from the manager asking me if I was coming over to pick up my 5 dozen assorted buns.  We were already battling traffic to get to the Bay Bridge, so it was too late to go back.  Besides, I ended up buying 4 dozen buns from another place close by.  I kept repeating "you didn't tell me you had buns, and I did go next door but they didn't have anything close to what I wanted".  Apparently, she had them made for me, but per our conversation the day before, I had no idea she was doing that.  She didn't ask for my name or number (but had caller ID) and she hung up on me when she told me to go to 625, not 621.  Still getting four stars because this place, by far, has the best steamed and baked pork buns and steamed chicken buns, in SF.  If the manager hadn't try to rip me a new one, I would have given this place five stars.  The communication needs to be improved if they are taking "special orders".  This place is closed until further notice.  :-(
author: CynCub C.

description:
Step 1: sign up for a marathon so you have an excuse to carbo-load

Step 2: feast on their incredible taro buns, giant char siu baos, sweet egg custard buns, and Po-Po quality doongs for the month leading up to the race

Step 3: skip race for early Sunday morning dim sum here instead

Note: I'm not a big char siu bao fan but decided to try one since they're reviewed well here. I found the inside to be a little too "gluey" with extra sweet sauce but the meat and actual bao were tasty.
author: Krystle S.

description: Fantastic potstickers (dumplings) and sesame dough dessert. Don't eat too much like I did... You won't feel well!
author: Daniel D.

description: This place has great sesame balls. The shrimp dumplings keep me hooked week after week. Its one of the better Dim Sum joints. Great value.
author: Ben M.

description:
Fresh, tasty, cheap baked goods. I visited Clement Restaurant on a Sunday morning and picked up: two BBQ pork buns, two taro puffs, one custard pancake, and one egg tart. The total came to just a little over $6. 

The place itself isn't particularly fancy, but the food sure tastes good. When I visited, there were a few other customers there. The staff works pretty quickly to get your pastries (or dim sum) bagged up quickly. Everything I tasted was delicious and the price is right. My only complaint is that the park buns weren't warm. (I was really hoping for them to be straight from the oven. Oh well, I just have to try again next time.)
author: Samantha L.

description: The vegetarian buns are not great but certainly not the worst. The mere presence of a vegetarian bun on Clement is a plus! Sesame ball is all right. $2.50 for a lunch is hard to beat, though (2 buns, 1 sesame).
author: Anne B.

description:
Their new canopy/sign caught my attention and since I'm always in the mood for Shanghai/Mandarin Dim Sum.
 It was after 6PM when I went in. I overheard that they have really delicious Nar Mi Gai. They do look somewhat smallish but I'm care more for quality.
Unfortunately, another lady ahead of me bought the last 3. 
Oh well, I got their Green Onions Flatbread. (Crunchy and still warm enough to be good.(Could be more flakey. Still better than most places in the City.) 

I also got the Sesame Daikon Dumpling and the Pork/Chicken Dumplings Combo.
I especially enjoy the Pork one.
They advertise that they have Xiao Lung Bao. The font was so big that I thought it was their name.
This "place" has 3 sections. BBQ is on the Left. Bakery in the Middle.
And Dim Sum is to the Right. I guess the Bakery and Dim Sum sections fall under "Clement Restaurant." 
Next time, I have to get there earlier to get some Nar Mi Gai.
author: Toeknee T.

description: This place was recommended by our friends from SF and they are popular for their Taro Puffs. I make sure before I leave town, I have, if not a box, boxes of these yumminess to bring home. I like how it's not too sweet and its flaky like a croissant :)
author: Carla A.

description:
(See pic)

So after food coma from Kabuto, I needed some walking around to digest. I saw this place before but never knew it's a big place until I saw the yelp picture that has the whole banner. I was attracted to the display of water chestnut cakes and black sesame rolls, my ALL time favourites since I was a kid. I peeked inside, there's a U line but it was moving fast. I cannot help but walked in.

And I have to say, the 2 items are just FRESSSSH and tasty. The black sesame rolls are just rich and cold. Those water chestnuts are like crunchy with juicy.

In addition to the 2 items, I also got the Chinese steamed plain buns, the egg custard (flaky style), the taro cake, glutinous cake and banana cake. I saw all the big steamers dim sum and the very pretty pineapple buns as well as Chinese doughnuts but was just too full even for the eyes to buy or gobble. Those will have to wait for the next time.

All the food I purchased were delicious, very delicious (clapping hands.) They were good because they're very close to the Hong Kong style that I am familiar with.

This place earns a few good stars and I surely will come back for more.

Now I really have to hurry up my French Women Don't Get Fat book...
author: T L.

description: Best potstickers,  fried shrimp dumplings on the block. Must try the curry beef puff donut looking thing. Amazing!  Looks like a big jelly donut,  but has savory curry beef inside. Very very good.
author: Lucy P.

description:
What restaurant? We tried to go based on all the good reviews, but only the bakery part was open, and the restaurant seemed totally shut down. [Monday night]
Maybe I'll go try the pick-up sometime, but we wanted a RESTAURANT so that we could sit down and eat. Ended up down the street. Need to find a place to take the family for something nicer than cafeteria style!
author: Ali W.

description:
I've been going to this place for over 30 years. You'd think they must be doing something right, right? Indeed, but it can also be a big disappointment. Although I like the food which, when it is hot and at its best, deserves 4-5 stars, the incredibly rude and unhelpful staff really brings this place down. 

The staff's attitude is not new. I remember when I was a kid one waitress (back then they used to actually serve you dim sum at a table as well as at the counter) used to literally throw the silverware at your face. While rudeness is not exactly uncommon in Chinese restaurants, the kind you'll experience at Clement Restaurant is not of the variety that you may have experienced at places like Sam Wo's (for those of you who remember that old place in Chinatown) where the staff was rude but in a friendly, jovial way. Here the staff is genuinely displeased with their work and don't miss an opportunity to let you know how little they care about your experience at the restaurant. 

Examples: So like I said the food is best when it's hot. While not so critical for the steaming goods, for the baked and fried goods that sit out unheated, timing is key. Either you have to be lucky or wait for the hot stuff to come out. But you may just be waiting for a hassle. Often I'll go in there and see them coming out with a steaming hot fresh tray of something good (like the baked baos). I'll ask politely for those hot ones instead of the ones that have been sitting there for awhile, and just about every time I get an argument from the staff who prefers to push out old product rather than please their customer. "Same thing, same thing" is their mantra. NO, it's not the same! 

Today  I didn't bother asking for the hot one's because I simply didn't want to deal with the staff. But after I paid I asked for a small cup of water (I needed to take some pills). "No water." Really? You made all this food but don't have access to tap water? "Only bottle water." I'm sitting there looking at a stack of small plastic cups (presumably used to serve something in) and asked the clerk if she could just put some water in one of those. She gives me a look of disgust and then says "75 cent." I told her that even McDonalds will give you a cup of water for free, but then said fine and then handed her a buck. She sat there and thought about it for a minute, and then tells me "only hot water, you want hot water?" I asked for my dollar back and left. Sorry folks, but when you go to a restaurant and are refused free water it is the ultimate sign that the establishment is inhospitable. 

Another thing to avoid in this joint is the staff's pushy insistence on knowing absolutely everything you might want right away rather than letting you select each item one by one as they get it. Maybe you need a little time to figure it out. Maybe you might buy more if you had a little time. Believe me I have little patience for those people who can't make up their mind and take forever, but c'mon.The other problems with this are that : (1) They don't always remember everything you ordered; and (2) They do the math in their head. Sometimes they get it right, sometimes they don't. Often you'll walk out without things you ordered and or without paying what you actually owed. 

Not long ago I peeked in the window next door in what used to be the dining area of Clement Restaurant. Now it's like a Panda-express style joint that I assume, but do not know, is owned by the same people that own Clement Restaurant. Some of the chicken looked good, but I've been burnt by crap of this variety before. So I went in and asked the clerk for a sample. She looked at me like I was homeless and started waiving at me to leave. Ok not your friendly local neighborhood butcher who takes pride in what they do and is happy to give you a free taste of something you might buy. So I offered to pay for a sample. "No, sorry, no sorry" and again waiving at me to leave. Hmm? You sell food. I will PAY you for it. Not interested? There was no one else in line waiting to buy anything. It could just be our little secret.  Ok, how much do I have to buy to make it worth your while to scoop up some of that chicken sitting there for me to try instead of standing there doing nothing? I finally managed to purchase a 1/2 pint. It was cheap and cold, definitely not worth the hassle. 

To be fair, there is currently one lady working at Clement Restaurant who is friendly and helpful. Give her a raise as she's all you've got going in the service department. 

Aside from the staff in this place, one also has to be vigilante of certain clientele who don't understand the concepts of a queue or personal space (you know who you are).  I can't tell you how many times I've been there where someone has cut in front of me in line, or bumped into me, without giving it a second thought. Again, not so uncommon in this city. 

Overall this is a place to go for cheap dim sum to go, but you will get better service at McD's.
author: Dan H.

description:
We went here THREE times on Saturday while shopping and popping into the local watering holes to watch the Niner's game. And we even waited in the longest line at the end of the day just because we HAD to get more luscious dim sum delights. I considered it a dim sum pub crawl, so to speak. Except we kept going back to the same place. ;-) The dim sum is amazing. Perfectly prepared every time. We love the fried shrimp balls and the crispy crunchy fried sesame balls. Also tried the steamed shrimp dim sum and baked chicken roll and the custard cups. They're all delicious. Just be careful, break into the sesame ball by opening it with your hands first to let the steam out before biting into it. Don't get so carried away that you bite into it immediately otherwise you will probably loose the roof of your mouth. Those things are HOT HOT HOT! 

Let's just say we filled up on so much dim sum that afternoon that we passed on our original plans to get Thai noodle soup down the street after the game. And my honey had a serious cold that day, so the soup would have been a surefire cure-all. But we just couldn't stop with the dim sum. It's just that good. 

I love this place. I can't wait to find another excuse to go back!
author: Steenie K.

description: Authenic quick Chinese food to-go! An order of rice/noodles with 2 side items for $5.25! Well-worth it for the price! Definitely will be back for quick lunch or dinner :)
author: Amanda C.

description: The BBQ pork is soooo good!  It's only $6.50/lb... so we grabbed some to go and scarfed it down as we drove.  Delicious and cheap!
author: Alex B.

description:
Pros: Cheap & good tasting food
Cons: Doesn't accept CC, small portions

This place is your basic small, grungy Chinese fast food store that has a lunch special of rice or noodles plus two sides for $X. There are actually tons of choices to pick for the two sides to accompany whatever main you want. I usually go for the chicken teriyaki and the rehydrated dried tofu. The other dishes are pretty much hit or miss for me. The sticky rice that they make here is also very good. Though the food does indeed get very greasy, it isn't that bad for the price that you pay. The one lady that is always at the register is alright. She is friendly enough to help with whatever questions I have about what a tray holds to how telling me how much longer the sticky rice will take until being ready. If you stick to getting their lunchbox deal it will come out to $5.25 and you will get plenty of food to last a good amount of your day. They have a second restaurant and bakery also and the bakery sells tons of different things. I usually get the taro balls which are delicious and makes traveling to Clement worth it.
author: Alex T.

description:
The holy grail of baked pork buns $1.00 each, stuffed with a big portion of tender sweet pork, scallions & bbq sauce.  The motherload is when you get them fresh& warm  outta the oven.

yummer-city.
author: Amy W.

description: We've switched our dim sum vendor from Good Luck to here ever since Good Luck put me on perptual hold on the phone.  Dim sum prices are maybe a tad higher than GL's.  I love their mini scallion buns (yes they are steamed buns with green onion in them).  $2 for 6.
author: Wendy H.

description:
* NOTE *

This review is for the BBQ section of this establishment.

I went back specifically for the brandy fried chicken legs because they were pretty marvelous in my opinion.  Crispy crunchy outer layer with a savory chicken meat on the inside.  I ordered 6 of the large legs.  $1.99 a pound.  I knew I was coming back.

However, this past evening, I walked down for these legs again and realized that everything notable Chinese closes right on the dot at either 6:30 pm or 7:00 pm.  Since I was already starting to get aggravated by the numerous CLOSED signs my puffy hair was on static alert by the time I reached this usual place of consolation.

FAIL.

Two people walked out with some hot foodstuff before us and this was ten minutes prior to 7:00.  The minute we walk in the double doors left open, the woman at the counter scowls and screeches "NO NO" at the top of her lungs and motions away with her gloved hands.  Her male counterpart says something back in Chinese to her, but she remained firm.

"What, you won't even sell that 1/2 cup portion to me?"

"NO NO," the scowling pony-tailed woman reiterates, without looking me in the eye, busy with placing leftovers in Chinese containers so that they could probably take them home.  "We closed!"  the phrase came back and slapped us in the face.

This was delivered, not in a courteous manner, where I might have left understandably and without feeling odd, but it was fucking rude.  And I said it, not that they would understand it.  "Rude."

I know these places don't really expound on customer service, but when I have experienced nothing but good customer service at Gourmet Dim Sum further along the way, I'm not one to stereotype all of the places on the block.  Put up a fucking sign that says "CLOSED" or give us an idea of your hours, that way I won't walk in over the threshold where you've left the two front doors conveniently opened.

Otherwise, I'll see if that rude woman is as rude on the weekends, when I can sneak back for the brandy fried chicken legs.  Despite this fucked up awakening, I'm still a sucker for something that is really really good.

And I'm not talking about great sex with an ugly man. 

Hell no.
author: Miika M.

description: if you want the best dim sum in Inner Richmond this is the best place to go. I visited here for a week and we got this everyday my step-grandfather told us this is the best and he's lived there forever. I got a double order of fishballs.A triple order of pork shumai and two red bean paste balls. And for dessert taro custard cakes. YUM! we always nickname it pinkbox for the bright pink boxes you reive the food in. But dont dilly dally because the staff can be a bit pushy but it is a smaller space.
author: Rowan L.

description:
Again, love the taro root puffs. So beautiful, purple, flaky, perfectly sweet but not too sweet. Looking forward to grabbing a box for my trip back home to Texas soon.

The teriyaki/sesame cookies are rockin' too. Chewy, toasty, almost caramel-y but with that great teriyaki flavor.
author: Leigh W.

description:
home of the bun nazi!

the lady has a less than happy mood but the food is so worth it!

I buy some of our share of food for the Buklod meeting here every month and i love that I can get lots of food at a fair price. 

big bbq pork buns, chicken buns, lap choy buns, all types of dim sum and chinese pastries to go!
author: Ray R.

description:
Review for the dim sum bakery-

I love this place.  Usually grab a box of char sui bao, a few coconut buns and potstickers.
author: Lyn D.

description:
7:30 am, a house of sleeping girls, plus me, the early bird. What to do? Duh, dim-sum! I woke up an unlucky victim and we hopped on over, found street parking (really difficult, even that early in the morning - we had to circle the block 3 times), and finally entered the land of delicious. We ordered shrimp shumai, pork shumai, baked cha siu baos, potstickers, turnip cakes, and sweet bread. Like, a billion of each. 

I don't know if it's because it was so early, or I was so hungry, or I love cha siu baos, but this was really good dim sum. Next time, you find yourself in the Clement district and are overwhelmed by the insane amount of dim sum places on this block alone, look for the bright yellow awning. No, not that one. Or that one. This one.
author: Katie H.

description: Everything is terrific!  I have been getting my fix of PORK BUNS there for 30 years and it's still my favorite!
author: Andie S.

description:
I am getting hungry just thinking about stepping foot in this place and ordering the...

1. BBQ chicken buns!!! (very unique taste than I have not been able to find anywhere else)
2. Fried Chicken (wayyy better than any chain fried chicken joint and much cheaper. the chicken legs are gi-normous!)
3. Pork Shumai (no other words to describe other than delishhh)

A couple other things to note:
- If you are driving up from the opposite side of the street and see a good parking spot in front of the restaurant, DO NOT make a U-turn to get to the spot. I've seen cops hand out tickets for this offense.
- If you plan to order more than 3 or 4 bbq buns, come early (like, before typical lunch hours). I've been severely disappointed on a few occasions when they've run out of buns. Sadface.

So go go go! Your tummy will thank you.
author: Kristina D.

description: Fav place to grab dim sum.  Love the shrimp eggrolls
author: Ayana K.

description: They have a variety of breads and pastries and also dimsum and etc. I thought the bread and pastries were fine, decent. Nothing exceptional but pretty good. Dim sum is good also. There are only a couple of tables though, which is better than nothing. I would say this place is cleaner than most dim sum/ chinese restaurants, which gives me a good impression.
author: Carmen L.

description:
They have the best pineapple bun.  The crust has great flavor and texture (not like the almond cookie-like stuff they affix onto the tops of other pineapple buns), and the bun is perfectly chewy.

The baked BBQ pork bun is also good here - correction - the best here.  Probably the largest chunks of meat in the bun I've had of any place, and the sauce and onions are perfectly balanced complements.  They may be more expensive ($1 each) than some other Chinese bakeries but they are SO worth it.

I keep finding new reasons to love this place.  Most recently I sank my teeth into the deep fried goodness of their curry and beef bun.  It's like a little heavenly fried pillow filled with joy.
author: Jenn C.

description: Combo $5.25... This means the staff don't get as good tips. :(
author: BigJohnS F.

description: Made the mistake of getting it here instead of my regular place. My regular place is just next door too. The cashier is rude and the food kind of bland.
author: M C.

description:
I've been here a couple of times over the years and remember not being that impressed with what I had (dim sum items).  Walking by, the items in the window never looked particularly appetizing.  But I kept hearing that they have the best Chinese buns in the city from trusted sources (I don't think I bought the buns in the past), so I returned to investigate.

They have a wider variety than most places since they have baked goods and dim sum, so you'll find egg custard tarts, loaf bread (Taiwan toast, red bean toast), 3 types of porridge, dim sum dumplings (3 for  $1.55), Chinese donuts, Chinese rice tamales, baked buns, steamed buns, mochi (coated in coconut), grass jelly, dried shrimp rice rolls, sponge cupcakes, and more.  The menu is in English.

* Steamed red bean buns: smooth and uniform in size and shape - professional looking and stamped in red on top.  There was a decent amount of filling inside, a smooth sweet red bean paste, though the first few bites were all bun, no filling.

* Baked red bean bun (80 cents) had a pineapple top.  I prefer plain baked red bean buns.  The pineapple crust top fell apart easily and made the bun too sweet.  The chunky red bean filling was delicious and the overall bun was heavy with plenty of filling and chewy, thick dough.  

* Steamed chicken bun ($1) was the best one I've had in a long time.  A delicate looking teardrop shape, the dough was tender and sweet and the chicken filling (think chicken meatball) wasn't salty or bland - it was juicy and had a stronger chicken taste than you usually find.  I liked the addition of cabbage too.  They even added a bit of ginger to the chicken filling.  Divine.

* Steamed vegetable bun - chock full of veggies, including carrots, wood ear mushrooms, clear noodles, cabbage, pickled mustard green

* Steamed combination bun - it's a monster, their largest steamed bun with chicken, cabbage, savory Chinese sausage and even a hard boiled egg - wow!

* Baked BBQ pork bun - filled with plenty of meat and some onions, the sauce is a bit too salty - Lung Fung has better BBQ pork buns

* Baked chicken bun - doughy and soft, with big chunks of chicken in a thickened savory sauce (mainly tastes like soy sauce).  Generous amounts of meat, a bit salty though.  The equivalent of the baked BBQ pork bun only with chicken.  I prefer their steamed chicken bun which is more delicate and less salty.  

* Baked tuna bun (80 cents) - sweet, soft dough surrounds a tuna salad with generous amounts of black pepper and onions.  The pepper makes it different.  Very tasty.  Update: I had another tuna bun and the filling was way too salty :-(

* Chicken and mushroom congee - good flavor, broken down and on the watery side, tastes like chicken vs. just water + rice, even has some ginger in it 

* Pork and preserved egg congee - quite bland and on the watery side, pork lacks flavor too, no ginger flavor.  The chicken congee is better.

* Har gow - decent but the bamboo shoots were hard.  I wouldn't get these again.  

Ample seating, not much in terms of ambiance - it's an old, inexpensive Chinese takeout Chinese/bakery so it has the ambiance you usually get at such places.  I've never tried the other side with the prepared food but my sense is that you should stick to the buns.

My trusted sources were right about the buns. Great price for heavy buns with superb fillings - be sure to get a couple of them, particularly the steamed chicken buns.
author: Lolia S.

description: Today the lady seem like she woke up on the wrong side of the bed.  I got to try their taro bun, but it was not as special as everyone make of it.
author: Lynn L.

description:
Coming from Jersey not to long ago we dont have anything like this place .. although there are tons in this city ... 

 I came to Clement Restaurant after waking up with a huge bun craving ... So i drove from the Soma to the Richmond and get my fix ... this place was the first I ended up driving to ... I arrived at about 7:45 am and everything was extremely fresh ... 

I ended up with a steamed pork bun, red bean bun, and some sweet bread with the white cream ... everything wad fantastic and came out to about $2 ... cant be beat ... my craving was met and my tummy was happy ... 

If its early and your around the area definitely try this place out .... its fresh, friendly, and cheap ... good combo :)
author: Anthony S.

description: The BBQ pork steamed bums were so incredibly good!  Also, there were these things that were round, steamed and with shrimp and greeen veggies.  I don't what they were called but you should put those in your mouth!
author: Christina M.

description: Popped in after driving in circles around Ctown for some char siu baos & dai boas.  Heard good things about this place so why not.  Glad I did.  I ended up with a dozen of both along with a dozen each of har gow & siu mai.  and let me tell you, they do not skimp on the fillings or sizes for what they charge.  I'll have to revisit this place again to test out the rest pf their offerings from what I'm reading on Yelp.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
This review is for the take out portion of Clement Restaurant. 

YUM

I always walk away from the counter wondering if they forgot to count a few of the buns I ordered. Today I left with 7 sweet buns for about $7. The sticky rice (it's wrapped in couple huge leaves) is sticky savory yumminess for $2.50 although I have yet to find the courage to eat all of the meat pieces inside. The rice reminds me of the sticky rice my middle school best friend's mom made on occasion. Otherwise, the taro bun (purple) and the long onion twisted bread with ham inside are my favorites. When I asked they didn't have BBQ pork buns at the take away counter, but I went late in the day. 

Since I live close by, I never eat in (nor feel compelled to) but would want to try the restaurant if it meant having the BBQ pork buns everyone raves about. Service is quick but don't expect friendly chit-chatter.
author: Jacqueline S.

description: Affordable and good dim sum to go. The prices are extremely reasonable, I think it was around 1.80 for 3 of the dim sum items and around 1.35 for the pastry items. The line here was long when we went, seems like a popular place for the locals. I would definitely come back when I'm craving affordable dim sum to go when I'm in SF. The service is nothing fancy, but there's not much to expect when it comes to these types of places. The line moves pretty fast so the wait time isn't long. There isn't much to say about this place besides the fact that it's good and cheap.
author: Vivian M.

description: Nice dim sum house.   Prices right and items tasted fresh.  Would go back if in the area.
author: Robert S.

description:
Definitely one of the better dim sum to go places in the city... but it doesn't do sit down dim sum any justice.  If I'm craving har gou on the go, this place is on my safe list.

Four stars for value!
author: Erika C.

description:
On Sundays after work I go to the restaurant side and order the lunch combo (rice or noodles and 2 others) only $4.80. Now that's a cheap price. It's just that sometimes some of the variety of foods on the steam table taste overcooked or worse, too greasy. But most of the time it's all right. The portions they give me are way too much, but I eat anyway since I'm always hungry. Maybe it's because I come to the place too often they know how much I can eat. lolz 

Anyway, if you're looking for cheap Chinese food to go on Clement Street, this is the place, the restaurant side.
author: Henry D.

description:
I love their pineapple baos filled with red bean paste!

The combination of the sweet azuki beans and the buttery taste of the crumbling topping on top of the bun makes my taste buds sing. I take a bite, shriek in happiness, take another bite, and the whole cycle repeats. At 60 cents a bun, it's definitely a steal! If azuki beans ain't your cup of tea, they also have a pineapple bun with a creamy egg custard filling (the same filling as nai wong baos) which is just as amazing.
author: Annie S.

description: Red Bean Buns!!!! My favorite since I was 6 years old! Always leave there with at least five dozen! The ladies look at me like I'm crazy. Yes, I'm crazy for RED BEAN BUNS!!!
author: Dee F.

description:
Dim sum = they have some of that.

Quick chinese take out = yeah they have that too... it's cheap and quick.  I'm telling ya though...there's some grease involved.

Roasted chicken, duck, or BBQ pork, and stuff of that sort...yeah they have it too.  

Go here if you need to pick up some quick food to take home...

Bring cash!
author: Fannie S.

description:
Even though I'm near Chinatown, I prefer to get my dim sum from this place. It all started wit h the rolled shrimp noodles they keep in the window. They are bigger, have more and bigger shrimp then all other places, and are covered with lightly toasted sesame seeds. They're much more delicious looking and tasting than any of the other dim sum bakeries. One noodle makes a complete meal for a dollar. Unfortunately I can never stop there and usually get shrimp & cilantro dumplings, or har gow. Mmmmmm. 

Hint: Go into the adjoining take-away restaurant and squirt some chili (near the cash register) and soy sauce (on the tables) into your dim sum container, to make it a little spice and ready to feast on.
author: Jenifer L.

description:
BARBECUED PORK BUNS!!!!! 
They have an enormous selection of menu items that I have enjoyed but 3 words say it it all "BARBECUED PORK BUNS" They have an awesome aroma, great texture and are the most amazing tasting pork bun I have ever eaten MMMMMMMMMMMM
If you want to impress your office bring a big box of those Barbecued Pork buns in
author: anita b.

description:
