Great News! Lunch here is 5$ for an entree and two sides! 

But, you get what you pay for.

The, Chow Mein is good, but everything else I've had has been cold and/or horrifically greasy and/or not very tasty.

If I wasn't a poor/lazy-ass college student on a fixed income, I'd never go here again, but as both of those things I'll probably take my suffering digestive tract back. 

One star for the price and one for the convenience (I live right across the street).
author: Casey U.

description: Forget the restaurant side, I have never gone to the other side of the wall. However, I have gone to the dim sum section of this restaurant numerous times and they do justice to dim sum. Good Luck Dim Sum is down the street yet I have not gone there because of the extreme long lines there. Clement Dim Sum has to be the best Dim Sum when it comes to fried taro dumplings, potstickers, xiu mai, steamed pork buns, and endless amounts of freshly baked pastries. The lady in front is fast and gets your order very quick while keeping the lines moving. I'm from San Jose and I just paid 16 bucks for dim sum in San Jose but at Clement Dim Sum, 3 bucks for the many options of dim sum I desire. 3 pieces for 1.50! How can you beat that? Parking is crazy since it is like China Town part 2 in the Richmond district but I don't mind when it comes to great authentic dim sum!
author: Danster L.

description:
Clement Restaurant scores well for its prices, but the dim sum itself didn't rock my world.  I had a good range of selections: char siu bow (pork bun), har gow (shrimp dumpling), fun gor (pork and peanut dumpling), and the pan-fried cilantro and shrimp dumpling.  

The pork bun was the giant, gut-buster size that I normally like (not the delicate fluffy little things with a speck of meat inside that you get at the big hong-kong style banquet halls).  It had a good ratio of bow-to-meat, but the meat was one-note in flavor: sweet.  Not bad at all, but it grew a bit tiresome quickly.

The har gow was the high note, a nice plump shrimpy delight.  But the fun gor is what really let me down.  The dumpling skin was hard (undercooked?), and unappetizing.  The insides were fine, but not lip-smacking good.

I'll keep on searching for great dim sum.  I didn't find it at the Clement Restaurant, but for the price, it did alright.
author: Laurence W.

description: This is the only dim sum togo place on Clement that I could find my parents' favorite black sesame rolls and they are delicious and a great value!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I'm only reviewing the bakery part of this three-storefront business. It's the one in the middle.

Clement BBQ has become my go-to Chinese bakery in the Richmond because of its location close to my home. It seems pretty average in most respects -- food, cleanliness, employee gruffness, etc. -- but they have a great selection of things to try and, true to their genre, it's some seriously cheap eats.
author: Todd H.

description:
Growing up in the south bay, I had forgotten what a Chinese bakery was supposed to be like. Most of the bakeries considered good nowadays are these sterile storefronts where you grab a tray and use tongs to grab your selection, or the pastry is already individually wrapped. They were fun when they first came around, but these bakeries have lost their souls and it's evident in their blah tasting, mass produced buns. 

Clement Restaurant's bakery reminded me of everything a Chinese bakery should be. Nothing beats the smell of fresh baked bread and that in combination with the smell of fried dumplings reminds me of family trips to Chinatown when I was a kid (to this day, SF to my parents is still Chinatown). While I stood in line trying to remember how to say my order in Cantonese, the female workers in the front were yelling to workers in the back when something ran low. I can't believe it's been so long since I've seen fresh dough being rolled at a Chinese bakery. 

And all of my favorite sweets treats were cheap: 3 for $1.55! The cocktail buns were so good and fresh. The pineapple buns are the best I've ever had. The bread was so fluffy and the sweet crust on top stayed intact. These pastries are all I've been thinking about all day. And oh how I've missed the pink box wrapped with that pink plasticky string. 

I didn't think it would be possible to pull me away from Good Luck Dim Sum, but I just might have to try Clement's dim sum next time because I'll definitely be making a stop here for the sweet stuff.
author: Mimi L.

description: Coming to to finish this review from a while back. Went here after a friend recommended it. We knew after the first bite and the food was cold this wasn't going to end well. Just got food poisoning. Thanks a lot.
author: Scott P.

description:
Clement Restaurant has some delicious dim sum: pork buns, shrimp & scallion dumplings, etc.  But the line can be very long, and the counter workers are "just okay" (rushed, & not especially anxious to be helpful).

Avoid their chicken rolls (baked with chicken, hard-boiled egg, & onion inside).  I once got very sick from eating one with the chicken practically raw inside--didn't notice til after I'd eaten most of it.
author: John S.

description: This place is definitely a to-go, the service is "get in, get out." However, steamed bun (pork or chicken)- is a yum.
author: Hanako J.

description:
I have very distinct memories of coming here with my dad and ordering boxes to take home and drop off to family members. You would think that after 20+ years of coming here the women (who are still the same btw) would at least give a twinkle of recognition....but nope. Either way, I can't be offended because they are so busy. 

I have gotten over arguments about the best dim sum bakeries in town and I will gladly throw-down over the honor of this place. I love everything about it from the smell of sweet chau siu bao drifting out the door to the pushy old ladies who always try to cut in front of me...hells no... I know that game. 

Even after all these years everytime I see a pretty pink bag with a pretty pink box neatly wrapped up I salivate at the thought of Clement st. 

p.s what happened to Clement st. it used to be the "real" Chinatown and every year it gets more gentrified...fuuuuucccckkk...damn hipsters and prepsters have to ruin everything!
author: Jade W.

description:
Best steamed BBQ pork buns in the city, hands down.  And for $.80, you really just can't go wrong.

They're big, don't have too much bread, and the filling isn't too sweet but has amazing flavor and is just the right amount for the total package.  Mmmm.

Lunchtime means a line out the door, and old Asian people will push their way to the front of the line, so just breathe deeply and think about the party that will soon ensue in your mouth.  The Cantonese women who work there are very abrupt and not very patient, but the food is cheap and good, so I can't really complain, especially since it's not a sit-down restaurant.

Things to note when eating dim sum take-out: it gets cold really, really fast.  And then it's not as good.  Their curry chicken empanada (well, the Chinese version of it) is REALLY good - one guy literally came all the way from the East Bay to wait for them to come out fresh from the oven, so I highly recommend it.

Be prepared to look for non-metered parking, and in the mornings they have trucks pulling up to deliver fresh animal carcasses to the grocery stores next door.  But it's all worth it for some really good dim sum, right?
author: Tori S.

description:
this is one of the reasons i love Clement and the Inner Richmond. Hidden secrets abound. my boyfriend once bought me these fantastic shrimp spring rolls from some store on Clement, but he forgot which one. We have been assiduously purchasing spring rolls from each store, trying to figure out the gem. And today we found it! It is Clement Restaurant! The Shrimp spring roll, great. We popped in, got 7 dim sum and 2 buns for $6.50. what a great deal.

SHRIMP SPRING ROLL.yyeeeeessssss
author: Jade L.

description: My brother and sister-in-law took me here for lunch one day and wow it's good! I've been back a couple more times with my fiance and we've had lunch or dinner and gotten buns to take home. Everything here is soooo yummy! I'm not very familiar with dim sum in general and at first let my sister-in-law order for me as she knows what I like. I particularly enjoyed the fried shrimp dumplings and their pork buns are better than any other's I've had. I've had several different things from here and have yet to find something I don't love. I need to plan another trip to the city soon!
author: Cedora C.

description:
CASING THE JOINT: Clement street, new Chinatown. Looks like a hole in the wall popular enough with the locals. Will try it out. 

THE SCORE: 

$1.55 for three pieces of dim sum. 

Siu Mai - savory, salty, delicious. Best dim sum I tried here. Average for dim sum siu mai, but the most flavorful of the bunch. 

Potstickers - not enough meat, too much veggie taste. Disappointing.

Fun gor - not as good as this place in chinatown in the city. Too much Chinese celery taste, not enough savory goodness.

Taro puff pastry - $1.25 each - redemption for checking this place out. Warm, tasty, sweet taro taste. Flaky crust overlaid a taro paste in the middle. Worth it. Want to try their taro bun as well.

THE GETAWAY: 

Slightly disappointed - hoping for some dim sum enlightenment, but just got dim sum ordinaire. Cheap, fill-me-up, let-me-down dim sum.

Will not be back specifically for anything but maybe a taro bun, puff pastry or siu Mai. 

Heading along Clement now for some boba tea to wipe that soy sauce out of my mouth.
author: Eric C.

description: Wow, this food is so greasy.  Oh well, 2 take-out items + chow fun for $4.80, get what you pay for.
author: Gerald C.

description:
This place is a poor man's Good Luck Dim Sum.

Went here because good luck was closed (it was a Tuesday) and saw the high reviews. I'm actually shocked how highly this place was rated. I got the following:

- Har Gao (dhrimp dumpling)
- Shark fin
- pan fried shrimp and scallion
- shrimp and leek

The har gao was actually quite good. Decent sized pieces of shrimp, and the skin was a good texture.  A little sticky and not too thick.  Definitely the best dish.

The shark fin gao was terrible.  the meat inside was oddly colored, (pink, purple-ish) and it was hard, like a fish ball, if you've ever had one of those. 

The pan fried shirmp and scallion was okay too, and I'd get that again.

The shrimp and leek were also terrible. I couldn't even tell what it was.  The skin was super thick, and it was just kind of nasty.

To top it off, the lady was rude and wouldn't show me the dim sum before I picked and they didn't have chopsticks.  

I've tried about a dozen take out dim sum places and about the same number of sit downs and this place ranks in the bottom half for sure.

Other than if the line is too long and Good Luck or it happens to be closed, I see no reason to go to this place (at least for the dishes I had).
author: Jason L.

description:
2 sides and an entree for 5 bucks - not bad at all.

But when I came in one night during late hours, my cheap ass self was looking for a discount (which some other restaurants do offer), but found none. 

Whatever, I was hungry and I wanted some fried tofu, eggplant and chow mein so I went for it while my buddies spent more money at a Thai place next door. My box of food made theirs look like a happy meal. I win.

My meal left me gassy all night. I win because my buddies had to suffer.

I probably would come here again (expecting a discount) if I happen to walk by at night.
author: Dorian T.

description:
Mutant yummy drumsticks.   They are the size of a good size orange.  How do they get this big?   

Anyways... its been a very guilty pleasure... but my Thursday morning breakfasts lately consists of the fried drumstick, a rice noodle roll with marinated vegetables, dried shrimp, and liberally sprinkled with sesame seed, and a thing of thousand year old eggs and pork porridge.   

Sooooo very good.  Everything super fresh.  Their porridge is best... good flavor and the pork is nicely marinated and flavorful.   

I've had their chicken pie which is good and their ham and egg bun is actually made with real eggs... none of that funky processed pretend egg mix thing.   

Their dim sum is bleh... but everything else... yummilicious
author: Regi K.

description: Ew. Gross. I've lived in the neighborhood for almost 10 years and somehow managed to avoid this place until now. There's some really good dim sum/Chinese hot buffet spots on Clement Street but this is definitely not one of them. I don't why I expected differently - it's dirty (really needs a deep cleaning), has a bunch of boxes of disorganized crap lying around, and there are only a few short stools to eat at. Food wise, it was a total grease fest and the meat was obviously low quality. Will not be returning and definitely not recommended when there are so many better alternatives on Clement.
author: Alissa A.

description:
I have been to Clement Restaurant a few times and although not a huge fan of their baked items , you can do really well with the lunch boxes at $5- that give a choice of 2 entree and one starch. 

Mixed experience with their chow fun from the steam table , but their fried rice is really good and the chow mien is okay. For entree choices there are a lot of options but my two current favorites are the prawn with vegi, and the chunks of cooked fish with vegi. I have had a hit and miss moment with the other items but the two seafood options were really yummy. Also a nice option if you need some Roast Pork or Duck and don't want to cook it yourself.

The staff at the steam table was nice but not sure they know what to make of someone that says thank you and please. Also not bad parking  during those hours meters are enforced just bring a few quarters and you should be okay.
author: Joseph A.

description:
The food is pretty good for its price. 

However, the staff is very rude. Typical right off the boat know it alls. For example, you say the name of an item wrong and they'll laugh at you. Or if they heard you say 6 when you really said 2, they insist on you being incorrect. They should learn some manners on how to treat your customers.
author: Jean T.

description:
BEST COCONUT COCKTAIL BUN EVER. 

the other baked goods are good, like the bbq pork. 

some of the non steamed dim sum are really greasy.

the steamed ones are good. 

this place is a must if I am in the city.
author: cheryl d.

description:
I come here once a week for the $4.75 deal for 3 items, basically the cheap lunch.  Last Saturday  & Sunday I suffered a massive MSG attack which lasted all day.

Needless to say, I'm never coming back.
author: Angelica C.

description:
Best pork buns in town?  Maybe years ago.  This was a childhood favorite and on a good day is still one of the better places in town to get a pork bun, but the last few times I've gotten them there, I've been really disappointed.  

My last visit, the steamed buns were wet and soggy.  Not steamed, but rather soaked with water like a sponge dipped in water.  Yuck.  Didn't realize it until I drove all the way home otherwise I would have gone back.  The time before that, I was so craving it that I ordered two for a quick snack and when I bit into it, it was still cold like they had just tossed them into the steamer a minute ago.  Now those two things are forgiveable, but I've also noticed that the filling inside the buns has been getting less and less sweet over the years.  Not sure what happened.  It used to be so good!!!  What's up with that?  Has the price of sugar gone up that much?

I do like their variety though and do enjoy their fried chicken and spring rolls.  Not to sound like Monk, but their glass case could use a good cleaning though.  Looks like it's been a few years.  I usually try to pick items that are not touching the glass.

Anyway, this morning, I discovered the baked bbq pork buns at Lung Fung Bakery which are downright heavenly.  Service is better and friendlier too.  Sorry Clement Restaurant, you won't be seeing me anymore.
author: Roy N.

description:
Yum Yum YUM!  Dim Sum to go...what a wonderful concept.  Popping a har gao or two at red lights while driving to your next destination is such an enjoyable treat for a gal on the run.

Everything I tried was deliciouso!  I cannot wait to return!  

Don't forget to try a warm sesame seed bun :)
author: Sarah Z.

description: I've been coming to this location for take away dim sum for 20+ years. In my humble opinion they make the best steamed and baked pork buns ever! Today (24Dec) I stopped in to buy some great tasting dim sum for a holiday party I'm going to, for the amount of food I purchased I couldn't belive the price; it's a deal! There's nothing fancy about this place , they have a couple tables at the back to sit and eat but most people just get a box of dim sum to go. Don't be intimidated by not knowing what some of the items are, ask the counter help or just buy one and try it, what have you got to lose?
author: David P.

description: My family has been coming here for years! It is seriously the best place to get pork buns and rice cakes! I must say, I am addicted to their rice cakes. I eat a dozen by myself in a day! Every time we go to SF we have to stop by here. YUM!!
author: Jillian O.

description:
You are still my fav.  If only you were a sit-down place and easier to bring guests/dim sum converts to...but then, you wouldn't be you!

Love,
Erin
author: Erin M.

description:
clement restaurant has been around for decades. they offer sitdown and takeout dimsum.

samplings: (takeout)
-har gow (3/1.55)partial pieces of crunchy shrimp with a few slices of ginger. bland
-sui mai(3/1.55)all pork,  was a little tough chweing, some gristled pork
sui mai was cold even though it just came off the steam table..
-baked bbq bun(1): cooked the old fashioned way with a gooey sugary paste intermixed with sliced bbq and bbq fat sinfully. yummy when hot. and it was.

leftovers
-some msg used
-a seemingly long line exists
-"large"  dim sum lady moves line fast. (much faster than skiinny youngsters at froyos)
-elderly chinese with middle aged white men in line.
-metered parking
author: Victor G.

description: Maybe one of the few to only places and the BEST EVER curry beef buns you'll have in your lifetime!
author: Meredith K.

description:
This is one of my staple grab-and-go dim sum spots in SF.  

Consistent quick picks for me are: 
1.  Hot dog pastry: There are 2 kinds.  1 that is rolled.  The second one which is my fav - has the sweet bread partitioned in 4 sections with 1 slice of hotdog/section.  
2.  Fried wonton stuffed with shrimp: 3 pieces/order  
3.  Baked bbq pork buns

And an ice cold orange Sunkist or Coke.  

Done & done.
author: Deanna A.

description:
Best buns ever, pork or otherwise. Not too much bread, not too sweet, and big pieces of pork, not scary mystery-meat. For the price (about $1) you can't beat 'em.

And, oh yeah, the scallion pancakes are very nom too.
author: Sophia D.

description:
I ate here for breakfast yesterday and everything was great. I'm in San Francisco on vacation and wanted to get Dim Sum while I was here, boy I am I glad I chose Clement Restaurant.

The Pork Buns are delicious, as well as the egg custard tarts and the har gow is pretty good. If you get the yellow shumai make sure to have plenty of soy sauce with it. The matuan was alright, but by no means the best I've ever had.
author: Nicholas Q.

description:
I've been coming here for many years and our family has favorites that maybe you haven't try before
Bakery section:  Pork sung/cheese rolls-they are usually available after 8am, shrimp/cilantro egg rolls. steam wheat pork buns, curry beef piroski,

lunch plate side: sesame chicken & salt/pepper chicken wings

If you're doing a party or get together & don't want to cook, you can order stuff by the trays or 1/2 trays,
author: May G.

description:
For: A Pork Bun by Any Other Name:

While the ambiance leaves much to be desired, the baked pork buns here are right on target.  If you're anything like me, then you try to get your mitts on a pork bun as soon as it comes out of the oven.  Hotness of the bun is nearly perfectly positively correlated with it deliciousness.

The outside of the bun is caramelized into this creme-brulee-esque shell that, once bitten into, gives way into the softest, sweetest dough that has just a little textural bite.  The filling is this pork chunks and caramelized onions suspended in hot, viscous syrup.  What makes the filling especially good is the balance between the bbq pork bun taste trinity: sweet, salty, and savory.  And you best believe that glistening sheen is from the copious amounts of cornstarch that bring this filling from a stew to a consistency more akin to sterno.  This is my pick for best baked pork bun in the city.  So far.

Everything else:
is ok.  Except for the siu mai, which, if propelled through a cannon, could bring down a small castle. Don't get me wrong, these dense-as-darkmatter balls taste alright, but are just too much to handle.
author: Thomas M.

description:
We call this the "Three-in-a-row" place - 
pretty tasty - a different selection of dumplings & baked goods than at Wing Lee down the way -
ALTHOUGH, while we were eating in, an old guy rolled into the kitchen a 50lb bag marked "MONOSODIUM GLUTAMATE" - I don't get any weird reactions to MSG, but it makes me wonder about the quality of the meat, that's all, just FYI
author: Robyn C.

description:
A nice snack spot for take-out.  

My Lady likes to drop in for a siu mai or har gow when we're visiting mother-in-law.  Today I think we grabbed four har gow and a couple of spring rolls.  The shrimp spring roll was all shrimp, and the veggie spring roll was all cabbage.  

This is for pocket change, like about $1  a piece.
author: David D.

description: My carnivorous pals and family members love their fried chicken drumsticks while their limited veg options are ok. they are good at taking orders and are very neat and precise about them.
author: R C.

description: I love this place to pick up my dim sum.  Not really room to sit down and have a chat.  Some of my favorites here: Steamed pork bun (they're huge and stuffed with yummy meat!), scallion pancakes (there's nothing like them when they are fresh!), shrimp hargow (sp?), fried pork mochi things (my bf loves these), and the baked egg custard buns!!!  Hands down my favorite cheap dim sum joint in SF!!!
author: Meli B.

description: yes cheap- and yes you get what you are paying for.....crap.   not sure why ppl like this place...i only tried the siu mai and shrimp dumpling ...
author: Rob C.

description:
Rudest salespeople ever; even by Chinatown standards. Give it a miss. They are a legend in their own minds.

8-10 persons stood in line while the leader of the saleswomen chatted on and on about immigration issues.  Anyone understanding Cantonese, from INS might wonder.

Sanitation - no comment.  1 block over - on the same side of street; great price; taste, and some service
author: Sunny D.

description:
My first Chinese food after moving to The City... and I was not disappointed.  For around $4.50 you get the lunch special, with a choice between a few varieties of rice or chow mein, and two other options; all being pretty good.  

This is a very get-in-get-out kind of place, with Chinese people pushing to get in and get their grub on, so ambiance isn't what they're striving for.  But for under $5 for a massive amount of food; be it stir-fried veggies, lemon chicken, Mongolian beef, and assorted very Chinese meat concoctions whiteys will steer clear of, you can't go wrong and will be quite full and happy.
author: Cooper S.

description:
I agree that the pork bun is amazing
The shiu Mai is horrible. I threw it away
The har gow is good
The shrimp and chive bun is very good

Would be more green if: their dine in plate wasn't disposable plastic
author: Christopher L.

description:
I only went to the take out side where everything is displayed in the cases.  Man this place is super super super cheap.  We only picked up some dim sum food.  The egg tarts were decent and super cheap.  We also got the fried dough with meat and veggies inside.  This was only so-so to me because I didn't quite enjoy the filling.  Everything was super cheap.  We walked out with like 8 things for the price of $2.  Yes, they are small snacks but for that price it's a steal.  Any starving person or student nearby would love this place.

Keep in mind that you get what you pay for and if you are on a tight budget.  This place would be great! ^_^ Next time I might be inclined to try the actual restaurant side if it's just as cheap! Money savers are great in SF! lol
author: Kat L.

description:
I learned Cantonese at CCSF and through my coworkers. I also learned the term Gwai-low. Gwai-low is slang for white person, which literally means scary-scary devil ghost. 

I went here today and tried not to act like a Gwai-low. This place has three connected shops, the lady on the far west side of the shop is very nice. I bought hot pepper fried chicken from her. She complemented me on my terrible Cantonese. She is a lovely person. I have eaten at the middle shop bakery, it is inexpensive and good.

The lady on the far east side overcharged me.  Am I really supposed to barter for tea duck? The sign said $9.99 but she charged me $12. Far be it for me to complain, but I swear she gave me the smallest duck. So, trying not to be a typical Gwai-low,  I asked politely about the price of the duck. She said the price went up. Apparently the price had gone up the moment she helped me, because the person ahead of me was charged "Sap" = $10. Aiii-yaa! 

TAAI GWAI LAA! Well, only the tea duck.

Update: My coworkers told me I was charged Gwai-low tax.
author: Mitsi M.

description:
What is the most offensive thing you can do to a fellow Chinese person?

Weigh the 1 lb of chow mein, then print out a sticker for the exact price in accordance to the price per pound, as opposed to "close enough and a little extra."

How do you make the wound smart more?  

Give the little Asian lady ahead of said fellow Chinese person the same weight worth of fried fish as the chow mein, then charge her only $3 when I know it's twice the price per pound.

Yes, I have manners learned by not growing up in the backwards old country, yes, I don't act like you b/c I think spitting/peeing/blowing my nose on to the street is akin to pestilence, and yes, I understand you even if you don't understand me.  Don't look at my blue eyes and pretend that you are so clever.  One day, Mr. Grasshopper, one day.  Feigned ignorance of the changing global situation may have worked in the past, but I think other fellow yelpers have been stung too by the price gouging just because we are not loud, rude and obnoxious like the people you are accustomed.
author: Christina C.

description:
There really could not be a more generic name for this place unless of course they dropped the "Clement" part of it. You can't swing a soy replica of an expired feline (I'm trying to be sensitive to our animal loving vegan friends out there, and you know who you are) on Clement St. without hitting a Chinese bakery/dim sum take out joint. So if they were trying to come up with a catchy name to differentiate themselves from the slew of other restaurants they failed miserably. 

That being said Clement Restaurant is my favorite. And it was no easy road let me tell you. When I first started coming here I thought the women who worked here hated me...and I was RIGHT! You wouldn't believe the attitude. It got to the point that I was tempted to say, "I'm half Chinese! Could you  just be HALF an asshole to me?!" I should have a card that reads, "Half Chinese; good for 1/2 off rudeness." Actually I don't think it would matter because I've seen some serious stink eye directed towards Asians as well.

Despite the unwarranted hostility I continued to come here. After about a YEAR the women finally began to soften and actually joked about how I got the same shit every time. No one has ever called me a quitter. The reason I endured such abuse for so long is that I just like this stuff better than the others. That, and you can get a BOX of it for like $10. It's enough food for three people (or MY fat ass.)

So if you have a thick skin, are cheap and have a hearty appetite this place may be just be your new favorite spot.
author: Josua P.

description:
Sometimes, a hungry girl with low blood sugar just wants to get an assload of dimsum without getting barked at, glared at or outright ignored for not being Chinese.  

Whenever I go to Clement Restaurant's dimsum bakery, service is  generally quick and friendly.  Today when I went, I actually received service with a smile.  And laughter.  AT me.  Why?  Apparently, everyone else loves this place, too, and bought out the first several types of dimsum and congee that I requested.  It was kind of hard not to laugh considering their abundant steamers, glass cases and window trays were loaded with delicious-looking items, yet I was striking out time after time.

Instead, I pointed at random items, asked what was in them and brought home a tasty variety of baked and steamed goods that I'd never seen at other dimsum bakeries.  Mmmm...mmmm good!  

The best part was walking away in a good mood because of the friendly service ... who likes to start off her day getting chewed out, anyway?!  Yay, Clement Restaurant!
author: Jenny K.

description:
This place is GOOOOODDDDD....

I live a block away from this place and this 2fer is definitely one of my regular spots for grub.

This place doubles as both an asian bakery and an asian fast food restaurant.  Its is really convenient!  And im sure that you would like to know that it is definitely nice that this place is cheap too!  Their bakery has many tasty and filling goodies that are all under a dollar!  Plus, a few of their goodies are 3 for 1.25.  Now thats cheap! :-D  I usually go in there and get a pineapple bun and a steamed pork bun, but they also have potstickers, soup, and other hot meal goodies to enjoy.

Now i will say that there are a few places on this street that feature rice and 2 items of food for 4 dollars + tax (I miss when it was 3.70 :-P)  But this place is by FAR my favorite.  Why you might ask???

Because unlike the other places on the street...you can get your two items with EITHER rice or noodles!  Let me explain...The other places on the street that offer the 2 item 4 dollar deal...say that the 2 item combo is only 4 dollars if you get steam rice and 2 items, and steam rice only!  This place is nice cause you can choose from their 2 or 3 selections of fried rice, or their 3 or 4 different kinds of noodle dishes, AND ANY of their two items :-D  That definitely makes this place my favorite.  Oh and it all tastes good too :-)

Oh and i should mention that i am really rating this place 4 1/2 instead of just 4.  I gave this place a little bit of a reduction because everyonce in a while you get a crankier then usual person behind the counter at either places, and even though it doesnt happen often, its enough to warrant a little bit of a deduction.  Oh and their cash only policy can be a little bit annoying at times, but i guess it makes sense considering its kind of silly to charge purchases under 5 bucks, since thats what a majority of their transactions are.

Anyway, if your craving some Chinese food that isn't 7 bucks for 2 items (Panda Express, Eeerrrrrrr :-P), then this place is definitely the spot to grub :-D
author: Mark R.

description: The best dim sum in the Richmond, if not the city. My parents used to have a dim sum date there once week when they lived in SF. Now that they have moved, I always make sure to bring them their usual from here, whenever I make a visit. My favorite is the steam pork buns & pot stickers. Delicious! :)
author: Lara G.

description:
This review is only for the lunch box side of the restaurant, not the dim sum side.

For one of my two items (plus rice or noodles), I asked for the tofu with mushrooms and bok choy. When I got home, I found the lady had picked out and given me only bok choy! WTF?! It was not a mistake - I saw her taking food from the correct item and there was no bok choy-only item.

At the store, I knew she had given me a smaller than usual piece of fish for the other item.

I went back and asked her if she is f*cking stupid? What did she think my reaction would be? She actually had to pick out the bok choy to be able to only give me bok choy. She didn't apologize (what could she say - she knew what she did) but gave me a few pieces of tofu and mushrooms.

She was not the regular lady but works the counter when they need two people. I'll keep going back and telling every employee and customer what she did. I'll tell the workers on the dim sum side as well. Just unbelievable.
author: Richard S.

description:
Okay, one more thing worth buying at Clement Restaurant:

FRIED TARO DUMPLINGS!!!!

Soo good.  So sooo good.  I came here a couple days ago for dim sum to go.  And the taro dumplings stood out above the siu mai and har gau.  Like srsly head and shoulders above, dude.  The consistency was perfect.  The bits of pork mixed well with the taro.  The fried coating was juuust enough to hold everything in when I bit into it.  Yet it was also so light.  Not drenched in frying oil, but light and crunchy.  Delicious.

And that, my friends, was enough to add one more star to my previous rating.   Yay Clement Restaurant!
author: Eileen P.

description:
Best steamed pork buns ever.  More BBQ pork in those than anywhere else and for under $1.  Buns buns BUNS!!!!

Dumplings/potstickers are 3/$1.50 and are soooo good.

Egg tarts!!!

If I ever walk by and need a snack for cheap, this is where I go.

Judging by the other reviews, I'm damned lucky to live only a block away.
author: Josh L.

description:
When I first moved out to the Richmond last year, I made it a priority of mine to find the best dim sum on Clement. This took some work--actually, I still have so many places to try--but using Yelp, I determined which were the best candidates and went from there.

Needless to say, I think Clement Restaurant is the best, at least for what I like: green onion pancakes, green onion and shrimp balls, custard buns, red/yellow bean buns, pineapple buns, baked chicken buns, and--my all-time favorite--sesame balls. The only thing I've had there that I didn't like was the vegetable bun, but there are so many other good things that I don't really mind. 

The food is tasty and cheap, but also easy to order. The women working the counter speak English and the menu board is written in both Chinese and English. There are a few tables at which to eat, but if you're taking your dim sum to eat on the go, be sure to ask for napkins (they won't give you any otherwise). The line can be kind of long at times, but it's totally worth it.

Edit (7/08): I've been wanting to try the baked chicken buns for a while (though I didn't write it before, I'm not the biggest fan of the steamed chicken buns), but they always seem to be sold out of them. Today, however, I was in luck! As I had hoped, the baked ones are a lot better than the steamed. Huzzah!
author: Katie I.

description: Bestie flew back for a couple of days, so we had a limited amount of time together. One of the things she really wanted was a lo mai gai (sticky rice and meat steamed in a lotus leaf). Actually, we really ended up at Clement Restaurant because Thai Stick was closed. Since it was a rainy day, we decided to just pick a random dim sum place and grab some stuff to go rather than walking around to look for another place to eat. She got her lo mai gais ($2.25 each) while I got some buns for my parents and grandma. My dad loves pineapple buns so I got him six (they're priced at three for $1.60). I got my mother three large steamed chicken buns ($1.40 each, I believe). I'm not sure if that's a good deal since I rarely buy dim sum or buns. They were your typical buns, really nothing out of the ordinary. What I really like about this place is that the ladies behind the counter are nice and speak English. The menu that's posted on the wall is easy to read as well.
author: Audrey T.

description:
This is probably the best Dim Sum Bakery in San Francisco. Good Luck Dim sum has nothing on this place, to all the Good luck dim sum lovers out there.. sorry! 

This place has the best BBQ pork turnover. Everything here is fresh and hot unlike good luck dim sum, where they heat up their items with a microwave. 

DID YOU GUYS KNOW THAT THEY USE REAL EGG in there ham and egg bun! SERIOUSLY! THEY USE A REAL EGG! NO GENERIC BULLSHIT EGG they usually use for the ham and egg bun at the other bakeries. 

I've been here many times and this place has never disappointed me in any way. The ladies that work behind the counter are so sweet, they have a smile on their face(maybe because i speak chinese), unlike good luck where they always frown and seem like that hate their job.
author: Brian P.

description:
This review might be a little biased (I've been raised on the dim sum from here since my grandfather started it over 30 years ago).

I absolutely love the egg custard tarts here.  The pork buns are effin awsome too.  Not much has changed since I had my first taste and that was in the early 80's.

If you haven't been here...come here.
author: Curt L.

description:
Mmm, hmm.....I could become a dim sum junkie.
I enjoy stopping by here & grabbing a snack on my way home from a long hard day.
Their BBQ pork buns are yummy, as well as siu mai, pot stickers and pretty much everything else I've had.
They are expedient so have your $$ and order ready when its your turn. No tomfoolery! Just deliciousess.
author: Claire S.

description:
THE SHORT VERSION

+ CASH ONLY
+ The food is delicious, and the prices are great.
+ Located reasonably close to a major bus stop on Geary

- This is NOT a place for five-star service. You go in, you order what you want, and you go. They are not there to answer your questions or take your crap -- you say what you want, they grab it, bag it, and hand it over.


THE FULL REVIEW

I've never really been big on Dim Sum -- not that I don't like it, I've just never been situated near a good place that serves it.

Until now.

My roommate recommended this place a few months ago, which means that basically it takes me forever to getting around to writing reviews. I visited this little quickstop with a pocket full of change and walked out with what I am pretty sure are some of the best damn pork buns in town. I started off safe and simple -- 3 steamed BBQ pork buns. The dough was sweet and fluffy and oh-so-delicious, and the meat on the inside was plentiful, flavorful, and best of all... piping hot.

In so few words -- This place has amazingly tasty food at prices that make broke college students like me weep tears of joy.

Since my first trip there, I've ordered a handful of things -- since I'm not too terribly familiar with the cuisine, I stayed away from things I couldn't pronounce. Thus far, I recommend...
- BBQ Pork Bun (Steamed OR baked)
- Baked curry beef bun
- Tuna bun
- Red Bean bun

I had a steamed chicken bun once and it was.. meh. It wasn't BAD. I want to put that out there. The bun was made correctly, I just don't like that style of prep for chicken.

As this isn't exactly a sit-down kind of place, I'm going to skip talking about the decor. It's a Chinese dim sum shop / bakery in the middle of the Outer Richmond -- you do the math.

A word on the service. It's fast, it's efficient, but it is NOT friendly. If you're the type to ask a ton of inane questions or expect some kind of special treatment, don't bother coming in. The staff there is not interested in doing anything but getting as many customers their food as fast as possible. You go in, you get your food, and you leave.


Good eating, folks!
author: Taylor S.

description: I love the steamed pork buns and sticky rice, but it's the fried curry bun that always calls my name! Don't leave with an egg tart. They are divine!
author: Ryan B.

description:
$3.70 Lunch Special? Can't argue with that.  Yummy Niu Nan and Sauteed Chinese Mustard (I think). MMM. Hong Kong-style Chow Mein was a little bland, but Niu Nan sauce fixed that.

Dim sum next door with huge and tasty Siu Mai! 3 for $1.50! Their Har Gao are deliciosly fat blogs of shrimp. Chicken drumsticks have a hint of curry to them. Dan Tat are flaky, but not the best I've had.

Ahhh, I love Clement St! Please relocate to LA Koreatown or Century City so that I can eat you all day everyday.

Here's a tip: The cranky ladies who bark at you from across the counter? Order in Chinese and they're suddenly nice and sweet (well, as much as possible for them). NEXT!

Duly noted: we have Valley Blvd., but it's way over in the SGV!
author: Albert H.

description: So cheap and SO good! My cousin and I were just pointing all over the place- 4 of these, 4 of those, some of that.  I think that's why the lady was getting annoyed with us. Any way, they had footballs!! They're these fried little doughy crunchy things that are a little sweet and salty with a pork filling. They're REALLY good!!! The ha cao and shu mai were average. I was new to the down and dirty dim sum in a bag idea (add soy sauce and shake), but I loved it! We probably got a whole feast for 4 for only 15 bucks! Great eats! be sure to look for the big yellow awning!
author: Vicki V.

description:
My favorite type of bun is a plain steamed bun, in Cantonese it's call "Maan Tau"

This is my absolute FAVORITE place for this.  Extremely soft, moist, great texture, and flavor.

I found out today, they also have a wheat "maan tau" there.  It does have the texture of chewing on paper, due to the grains.  But, it doesn't taste half bad.  It's a good thing to have for those health conscious people out there.  

In short, BEST PLAIN, STEAMED BUN aka "Maan Tau" in SF (from all the places I've tried and I've tried many!)!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Michelle Y.

description:
4 stars because this is my neighborhood Dim Sum place and I have found it to be the best Dim Sum place. It's also very very cheap. 1 dollar for the Baked or Steamed BBQ Pork Buns, and 1.50 for 3 pieces of Har Gao or Shu Mai. 

I've never tried the other parts of this restaurant, but they don't look too good/shady.

I'll dock a star because these are some of the things I'm concerned about:
-The cleanliness of this place.  I don't think its too clean, but its pretty good so I'll turn a blind eye.
-The service. I mean they are Chinese ladies in a hurry. It's basically this: 
Dim Sum lady: What you want?
Me: 1 BBQ Pork bun and 1 order of Har Gao.
Dim Sum lady: 2.55
I hand her money, and she hands me back my change. The whole time though she is snapping at me, not asking me what I want in a cool or collected manner.
-There is no place to sit and eat. It's to-go only unless you go to the other side of the restaurant. 
-I once saw a wood crate of pigeons being brought to the back where the kitchen is.
-The food is really hit or miss. Sometimes, the buns won't be warm or the Dim Sum will taste a bit off. I'm not sure what it is, but it's not very consistent. However, it is hit more than a miss.
-Parking sucks.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I've been going to this dim sum take-out restaurant for years, and little did I know its name.  To be frank, it's a bit strange that a tiny, narrow restaurant with maybe three tables is called Clement Restaurant...like it's THE restaurant on Clement Street.  

It is however, THE restaurant on Clement Street to get your sweet and savory buns, pot stickers, shu mai (pork, chicken, shrimp or beef), spring rolls, hau gaw, jook and the like.  The baked pork buns and steamed chicken buns are my favorite as they're adequately stuffed and the bun itself has a good taste.  It's such a popular place that the turnover is quick, so there's hardly ever a bun that's been sitting there for hours on end...makes for fresh buns almost every time I go. 

Lines are long during the day on Saturday and Sunday, but it's definitely worth the wait. Staff are quick and efficient for the most part.  I don't speak a lick of Cantonese and order by pointing or saying the English name for everything, but they get my order right.

Go for quick take-out dim sum.  Everything you order will be fresh and still slightly warm.  Prices are reasonable and staff are quick and usually efficient.
author: Marie B.

description:
Absolutely the best!

I always get their potstickers, baked or steamed pork buns and sesame balls.  The dessert items are wonderful too. I have my family hooked on their coconut tartlets and I really like the plain cupcakes.

This place always makes my day feel complete!
author: Danielle H.

description:
Bf loves the raisin buns here which often sells out fairly quickly. The curry beef puff, fresh soya milk, steamed BBQ pork bun, lotus paste bun, sesame balls are all tasty and at great prices.

The takeout place next door stirs up a storm too with delicious dishes and rice/noodles for less than $5!
author: Yan M.

description:
This place has the greatest baked BBQ pork buns I've ever found. The potstickers are also delicious but the siu mai left something to be desired.

That said, I started to read some reviews right before I took my turn to write one and noticed that the topic of MSG seemed to pop up pretty frequently. Out popped the wikipedia page for MSG and it turns out that people need to stop being so scared of the stuff:

"In the 2004 version of his book, On Food and Cooking, food scientist Harold McGee states that "[after many studies], toxicologists have concluded that MSG is a harmless ingredient for most people, even in large amounts.""

With that, any worry I had that I wouldn't get to enjoy the sweet and delicious baked pork buns from Clement washed away. I can't wait to go back and have another helping (with extra MSG!)
author: Dave B.

description:
You need to get the BBQ pork, ask them to chop it up, then bring it home and put it in your noodles from Yuen Hop.

But don't ask for any measurements other than 1/2 lb increments.  Trust me.
author: Rob W.

description:
Where else can you feed a bunch of hungry, snarling kids for under 20 bucks? Give a hungry kid one of their pork buns and they shut up fast! 

They have the best pork buns (we like the steamed ones) in the City, bar none. We also love their siu mai, they are HUGE! 

The counter ladies are very efficient, but not the most "customer friendly". If you're a newbie to dim sum, I suggest you don't come on the weekend before 3 pm. You need to know what you want and how much you want as soon as the counter lady's gaze meets yours. Otherwise, the evil dagger eyes come at you from all sides....the customers waiting behind you and from the counter lady. 

I'm happy to say I've never been a recipient of "evil dagger eyes", my mom taught me how to order dim sum since I was 8. I have only bared witness to many unfortunate tourists!
author: Mitzi R.

description:
Best baked pork buns in town. Hands down. Anything else you get here I cannot be responsible for but you seriously have to get the pork bun. Whether you eat at the restaurant or go home with it... I might recommend you go home with it... but yeah this place has great pork buns. The shrimpballs, meat balls, potstickers are pretty mediocre. But they have the best pork buns on Clement St

The decor is pretty well established and ancient. The ladies are apparently not interested in your day other than what you want to eat. But the key thing is that you enjoy the pork buns.
author: Alexander L.

description: The pork buns are SO good and everything is super cheap!  The line was long, but it moved quick.  An awesome place to pick up dim sum to go.
author: K V.

description:
I hadn't had dim sum in a good long while so I went with two friends yesterday morning before heading to the museum. Somehow I didn't realize that it wasn't really a sit-down place (can't read, I guess) but we stayed anyway because I was about ready to gnaw someone's arm off, I was that hungry. It was easy to pick out what we wanted because everything was clearly labeled (in English!) which I haven't come across too often, especially in Chinatown. I chose a few of my favorites - turnip cake, shrimp & chive dumplings, baked pork bun, wu gok - and threw in a green onion braided roll and a bottle of water for good measure. My total? $6.90. Freaking amazingly cheap for that much food, especially since I got three dumplings and two slabs of turnip cake.
Due to the lack of seating, we took our treasures next door and went to work. My friend attacked her fried chicken leg like it was her last meal - I didn't even have a chance to nibble but it looked tasty. I was so excited to dig into my turnip cake but it was cold. Like, from-the-fridge cold! Super bummer, but I saved it to fry up this morning (awesome!). The baked pork bun was steaming hot though and filled with delicious BBQ pork. Too bad I had a bite that was basically one big glob of pork fat - ugh. The wu gok was very good - the puff was fried crisp and the pork & taro filling had good porky flavor. The shrimp & chive dumplings were also very good but I wish there was some sort of chili sauce readily available in addition to the black vinegar; the dumplings were a little bland and could have used some spice. The green onion roll turned out to be my favorite - they used a sweeter dough than I'm used to (almost tasted like brioche?) which was a great contrast to the savory onion flavor.
Minus a star for the turnip cake served cold and the fat in the pork bun. Also minus a star for serving my friend a shrimp dumpling when he asked for cilantro - he's allergic to shellfish and could have had some potentially serious consequences. Other than that, pretty good for what it is!
author: Stephanie S.

description:
mmmm. dim sum to go. what more could you want?

the siu mai and ha gao are pretty standard. not gross, not mind-blowing incredible. they sell jook, cheong fun, lo bak go, zong, the standard dim sum things. where they shine is their different bao. the cha siu bao, the baked chicken bao (which has a hard boiled egg inside!!!), the taro bao!!! mmm. their taro breads are goooooood. the dan tat is meh. get the taro stuff. 

be prepared to battle the old chinese crazy ladies who will push past you to get their dim sum. the workers seem to know english, or at least understand my super broken cantonese+hand gestures. anyways, it's cheap and it's tasty. me likes.

oh, and don't eat here. it's cleaner to eat on the street, standing up.
author: Aletheia W.

description:
During my USF days, this was my go to place when I had a craving for some dim sum.  

For under ten bucks I could get an order of :
- Har Gou
- Pork Siu Mai
- Taro Root
- Steamed BBQ Bun

There would always be plenty of left overs for me to have after a visit.. Years go by and I still find myself coming here even though I live in the Peninsula.. This place is good and the prices can't be beat!
author: Trish P.

description: FAST, fragrant  and HUGE bowls of Pho!  Most bowls can be ordered in small, medium and large but the most popular one only comes in large. Had the imperial rolls and spring rolls too... very good. I will be back here on my next trip to San Francisco.
author: Wood G.

description: baked bbq pork buns are awesome here.  i'm not a big fan of their pork shumais.
author: Kurt N.

description: I love the pineapple buns. It's all about warm, soft, springy, chewy, slightly sweet with the crumbly orange-yellow top layer.
author: Dee I.

description:
out of all the chinese bento places on clement, this one is my favorite!  i have been to a few but i think the quality and taste of the food here is really good, reminds me of home.  even their bbq selection of roast duck and roast pork is better than the others.  for a total of 4.80, you can stuff yourself silly with your choice of white rice, chow mein, chow fun, or fried rice and any two of their dishes.  the variety isn't extensive but there's a lot to chose from.  they really really pack their bento box generously so this can actually extend up to three meals for me!

in addition to being the best, this place is also the closest to where i live.  the uncle and auntie behind the counter is getting to recognize me and they are so nice to me!  a good tip is that you should go when they're close to closing time 6:30ish-7pm.  if you are capable in speaking cantonese, chat them up with charming small talk and they might add in a 3rd dish for you on the house.  they did for me!  ;D
author: Irene W.

description:
the fried chicken drumsticks are big & meaty and taste like home made

if you come here after 5pm they are extra generous and give you more than you can eat or say it's on sale and give you a lower price than usual

the dim sum is also pretty good, one of the best ones on Clement
author: Mr Bolo B.

description:
This is really not as good as I expected. 

I had the pork/thousand year egg porridge, shrimp dumplings, xio mei, egg custard tart and baked BBQ pork pastry.

Shrimp dumplings are alright, although one of them actually had rotten tasted to it. Xio Mei tasted terrible. The worst Xio Mei I've ever tasted. 

The porridge was very liquidy, not rich nor thick, almost tasteless. It is supposed to have only lean pork but there was a lot of fat in it. Pork was very tough. 

The baked BBQ pastry.... God, I couldn't even finish it. Threw it away after I had a couple of bites.

The only good one was the egg custard tart, which is why I gave it 2 stars. However, the crust was very thick, and the custard part was small. No where close to the ones from Golden Gate Bakery.

It is cheap, though, I have to say. All these items I mentioned above cost me less than 8 dollars.

However, I much rather spend a bit more for much better quality food.

I didn't try the BBQ pork buns. I might go back to try that next time. Otherwise, I am not going back again. Totally not worth it.
author: WS P.

description: This place is not a restaurant!  The name is misleading.  It's a take out spot.  We came here with a family of six and wanted to sit down to eat.  No chance.  Just a warning for others who come here thinking it's a family style restaurant.  On the plus side dim sums and pastries were good to great.  Price was quite reasonable!  Good for a take out...
author: Norcalscot L.

description:
I grew up on this food. My dad worked in a very bland office around the corner but the saving grace was that he was on Clement Street so whenever we visited we knew we'd eat something amazing.

 I was having a physical craving for this place on my latest visit home. It was like a magnetic beam forcing me to trek from my parents' place in Novato. I could practically hear it calling me. I hadn't counted on the evil, hellish nightmare that driving on Clement Street on a Sunday has become. It was always bad, but holy crap the traffic, the stupid stopping in the middle of the street are enough to drive a peaceful man to murder. And if that's not enough, the lines dragging to the back wall were almost enough to have me go somewhere. But I persisted, even the 100 + year old man behind me who started ordering before his turn and then kept pushing me for no apparent reason didn't stop me from ordering a huge bag of delicious curry puffs, corn thingys(which I've never seen in any other dim sum), pork buns and dumplings. I think I ate most of them before I hit the bridge. The steering wheel of my dads car was a greasy mess.
author: Jeff G.

description:
Whenever I can't deal with the 30 minute waits that Good Luck Dim Sum sometimes has, which is beyond crazy, I go here.

There are 2 sides to this joint. The dim sum/bakery side and then the steam table take out food side. The dim sum here is pretty good. The things I would recommend are:
 
shrimp dumplings
pork dumplings
steamed chicken bun
dried shrimp noodle (super good!)
green onion bun
pineapple bun

For those of you who like porridge (jook) the pork and preserved egg is good. The peanut and dried fish is a nice change.

For the take-out side, when I'm in the mood I go for the lunch special. For $3.50 you get 2 sides with rice or chow mein or chow fun. And there are a ton of side dishes to choose from. Sweet & sour pork, fried fish, fried chicken wings or drumsticks, beef stew, beef tripe with liver, fish with bell pepper, fried sardines, ma po tofu, 2 kinds of seasonal veggie stir fry, curry chicken, salt & pepper shrimp and that's all I can remember at the moment. It's not the most healthiest but for that price, it's good as a treat every now and then.
author: cyndi L.

description:
If I could give 3 1/2 stars, I would. It isn't that bad.. and it's cheap. That is always a plus for me. We thought about trying other places for Dim Sum other than the place we usually go to on the weekends. So, we decided to try Clement Restaurant. 

For all we bought (Har Gau, Siu Mai, Dry Shrimp Crepe, Chinese Donut, Potstickers, and BBQ pork steam bun) all for only $8 something. Dirt Cheap!!!  But, I'm really picky about my dim sum. So, they didn't really win my attention. Anyway, hubby said that they do have GOOD bbq pork buns ($.80). He loves bbq pork buns! 

Here is why it's not the winning dim sum for me and I choose Good Luck Dim Sum way over this one:

- Har Gau- the skin is too thick and not enough shrimp in it, unlike Good Luck Dim Sum, the skin is thin and they are loaded with shrimp. 
- Potstickers- mine were cold although they were good, they weren't crispy. Too bad!
- Dry Shrimp Crepe- it was cold and no sauce to eat it with.. disappointing! 

But, they do have something I like, such as Chinese Donuts. Love them, especially with porridge! Yumm! Gotta try it:  hot porridge with egg on the bottom with slivered of Chinese Donuts on top! Ahhh... 

And another thing... they DO speak ENGLISH!!! and they are pretty nice, unlike other places, they are so much in the rush that they appear rude. So, that is always a big PLUS for me!
author: Daisy S.

description: MMM CUSTARD BUNS. 6 PACK of custard buns . legit
author: Chantel Y.

description: We stopped in for brunch.  Our simple meal consisted of rice porridge and a few dim sum selections.  We ate it all on a very cold and rainy San Francisco day.  We liked it, recommend it and would come again!
author: bruce f.

description: Nothing like sinking your teeth into a fat potsticker!  or a cilantro dumpling, or har gow, or siu mai!  The steamed pork buns = wow.  All so delicious and loaded with filling.  And all so reasonably priced.  $20 will get you enough food to feed 6 people.
author: Keeping It Real K.

description: THIS PLACE IS THE BOMB DOT COMB . I DO NOT NEED TO REPEAT MYSELF . Although I dropped in here with a friend about 1 month and a week ago I STILL REMEMBER IT CLEARLY AS IF IT WAS THIS AFTERNOON . My friend and I were strolling around the streets of clement with cheap tapioca and my friend wanted to eat some asian bread. So I was liek WHY NOT . But then as I was about to order asian bread for her , on the menu , I saw PEI DAN JUK . If you do not know what that is that is preserved egg porridge. IT WAS REALLY GOOD. Pretty large servings fit for two for only $2.50 . LIKE OMG . Plenty of Pei Dan(egg) and plenty of  PORK . like totally . lOL . ALways in and out with people.  Kinda small place though, IF THEY REMODEL I BET TONS OF PEOPLE WOULD EAT HERE THAN JUST GETTING TAKE OUT OK . So me and my friend were one of the very few awkward people who actually stared there to eat LOL . And my friend has very bad cantonese must I repeat myself, She kept practicing how to say the word Pei Dan Juk . For the reason idk why . But she kept screaming it over and over and over for at least half an hour. I tried teaching her other words in canto so it won't make it seem liek we're crazy. It's like you work in a mexican resturant and you only know spanish and these foreign people keep screaming Taco so you must get the impression they love it . Yeah those workers probably thought we were crazy and was obsessed with pei dan juk . They probably went home and told their relatives LOL ahah . BUT AS LOUD AS WE WERE THEY WERE POLITE AND DID NT JUDGE US OR TELL US TO BE QUIET. +1 STAR FOR THAT . Also my friend brought outside bread and tapioca and they did not judge us. ANOTEHR STAR . Overrall, quality pei dan juk, better than that nasty D&A cafe down the street . I WARN YOU DO NOT GO THERE . IT IS LIKE $5 FOR PEI DAN JUK AND IT IS TERRIBLE . MORE LIKE JUST WHITE PORRIDGE WITH NOTHING . HERE You CAN GET QUALITY PEI DAN JUK FOR ONLY $2.50 .Overrall successful day, we left with smiles on our faces ok . I GIVE YOU 5 STARS OK . 5 STARS FOR EFFORT AND I HOPE THIS PLACE GOES BIG ONE DAY AND THANKS ME FOR THE 5 STARS LOL AHAH OK .
author: Stephanie D.

description:
This review is for the BBQ (left) side of the business.  Since I usually get take out, I've never tried the restaurant side.

The BBQ Pork is outstanding.  Everyone who I've ever shared it with, loves it.  The pork is hanging in the window.  You tell them how much and they cut it up for you.

The Peking Duck is very good.  If you only want 1/2, they'll do that for you and cut it up.

To the right of the cashier, they have a roast pig.  I tried a piece once.  Compared to the BBQ Pork, it wasn't for me.

To me, the Chow Mein, Fried Rice and other buffet style dishes are not has tasty as other places; such as Wing Lee http://www.yelp.com/biz/wing-lee-bbq-restaurant-san-francisco

That said, I don't know of a single restaurant in San Francisco that does a better job with the BBQ pork.  Plus, all their prices are very reasonable.
author: Roy C.

description: It's one of my favorite places for pork buns and picked up some last week to take into work.  I've tried other things there, but am always brought back because of the pork buns.
author: Bill P.

description: STEAMED BBQ PORK BUNS!!!! at only .80 cents this is the most delicious lunch i have ever had. After i finished i bought another for the road. My only criticism is that it was a little too much bun, but i ate around that to the porky deliciousness.
author: Ashley G.

description:
A hole-in-the-wall take-out dim sum restaurant and bakery (emphasis on the bakery).  Great value for the price.  For example, baked pork buns are $1.00 and steamed ones are 80c.

Next time, I'll have to get more of the black sesame sticky rice rolls.  The butter-coconut rolls and taro mochi were great as well.  I need to try out more of their desserts!
author: K L.

description:
I'm only giving two stars at the moment because of past good experiences.

Today, I bought two sesame seed fried balls, and in the red bean filling (or it USUALLY is only red bean filling) I tasted barbeque sauce. 

That's right.

Barbeque Sauce. Not satay, but friggen, barbebque sauce I'd have on my burger, ribs, or chicken McNuggets. W-T-F?!

I thought it was just my taste buds, and finished the first one, thinkin' that maybe a dab of bbq sauce fell in the mix.

If that were so, the second sesame ball confirmed that the whole friggen bottle fell in cuz every time I took a breath after biting in the second sesame ball left me tasting barbeque sauce. I chucked that piece of crap out readily, and I'm pretty sure I'm ready to go back to the dim sum stop down the block.

Sorry Eddie and Mel, but your parents' former restaurant just about killed any fond memories it used to have from our childhoods. That's right, I knew (a past?) owner of that same restaurant at that same site, and had been going there for years since I went to elementary school not half a block from that at George Peabody. Dang it, Clement Street, change into something for the better please.
author: Patrick K.

description:
Just to level-set, this is take-out.

There are many places like this one on Clement St. in San Francisco that have a take-out counter with Dim Sum-type dumplings. I've tried 4-5 of them.

All of the dumpling take-out places on Clement St. charge about the same price - give or take a few cents.

Of the take-out dumpling counters on Clement St., Clement Restaurant is the only one that regularly has deep-fried dumplings. So if you're looking for deep-fried stuff, this is the place to go.

But for take-out steamed dumplings, there are better places on Clement St. - try Gourmet Dim Sum, only a few doors away. (See my review for that.)

(Note: Clement Restaurant has 3 separate doors, each with its own food counter; the middle of the 3 doors is the one that sells dumplings. The left door sells full plate lunches, while the right door seems to sell leftovers from the left and middle doors?)
author: Gregg K.

description: Thick chow mein, savory limon chicken, flavourful tofu: less than $5 to impregnate your belly with grand nourishment. Nice!
author: Haz O.

description: msg update: just don't eat a lot of these if you're msg sensitive. I have gotten migraines after eating them for a couple days straight.
author: Blue R.

description:
so i'm walking down clement tonight night and my friend calls me and says "i see you. walk in the direction of the green light that you see" and i start walking and i find her standing in front of this restaurant and still on the phone with her she says "i'm standing of front of this place, looking in through the window and i see 3 rats running around on the floor!" so i finally catch up with her and i said "hey, this is the place where we got food last time!" and she laughed and said "yup! but ewwwwwwww" and i start looking in through the window and sure enough, I see Remy the rat scurrying on the mopped floor enjoying his friday night! 

anyway food wise, it's cheap and decent if you want something quick. I do like their fried chicken drumsticks.
author: kristin e.

description: Rating their exquisite deep-fried taro dumpling: nicely flaky on the outside and tasty on the inside. Made of cooked and mashed taro enclosing a ground-pork filling, it's the perfect size because if it was any larger, there wouldn't be the right balance between the crunch of the fried taro exterior and the moist and soft meat that lies within.
author: Cliff W.

description: came in for some roast(crispy skin) and BBQ pork to go, it was HELLA dericious and for only $5.50 per lb.
author: Pickle R.

description: Well....at 3pm, this dim sum was not good. It was hard, cold, and just...not that great. Sure, I still stuffed three chive/shrimp dumplings down, 3 potstickers, and a fried-doughy-meat-ball, but it left me feeling ick. But, I got all 7 pieces for a mere $4.20.
author: Misha F.

description: Got this coconut sweet bread muffin thingy that was fresh out of the oven 3 days ago....and I can't get it off my mind.  Freakin' amazing.  Oh yeah, the dim sum was awesome too!
author: Stacey M.

description:
the rice plate is a good buy...
you get 2 items for $4.80 tax already included...
i got the shrimp with mix veggies and
fried fish with bell peppers and black beans
over white rice..yummy

you can sub white rice with either fried rice or chowmein...
the portion is pretty  big...=)
author: Laimei W.

description:
I wanted to do catering but their take-out was closed on the right.  One of the dim sum ladies in the middle restaurant sent me to the BBQ place; told me the same kitchen made food for both.

You'd think they would be excited to get a bulk order.  But nope - no acknowledgment.  Not even eye contact when I attempted to initiate the order.  It was Saturday afternoon around 4PM and there was a steady flow of customers.  I went past the BBQ counter to see if they had menus further back and almost fell on my butt on the quarter inch of grease on the floor.  When I grabbed the counter to steady myself, I touched more grease.  Gross!!!!!!!!!!!

The bottom of my tennis shoes were so slick by then that I literally skidded out of there.  And since I couldn't move very fast, I paid more attention to my surroundings and that's when I noticed the rusted stool bottoms, food splatter on the walls, and oil streaks on the floor.

I will NEVER order from this place.  Y'all eat here at your own risk!
author: D C.

description: One of my two favorite places in the world to get bbq pork buns and other dim sum to go.  Quality product, not too sweet, not fatty or chewy bits.
author: Mark M.

description: This is the place for steamed BBQ pork buns.  There is no other as far as I'm concerned.  I made many trips on the 2 Clement to this place when I lived in the City.  Now some 30 years later my daughter is living in the City and when I go to visit her this is a must stop at place each time we get together.   It hasn't changed a bit in all those years- still cheap good food and the same not terribly friendly but efficient counter people hustling you along to order and keep the line moving.    They take credit cards but only if you spend over $10 - which in this little place is tough to do - all their yummy food is very reasonably priced.
author: Cindy D.

description: When I'm in town, I always stop by here for some pork buns to go. They are absolutely delicious. Get there early. Parking in the area can be tough. They have THE best egg tarts too.  I always look forward to going here. Check it out!
author: Theresa N.

description: I dig on their pineapple buns, pork buns, egg custard tarts, and their raisin twists and that's all I can vouch for from this place. My aunt and mom love the yellow blocks of water chestnut paste and the black sesame rolls, but that isn't how I roll.
author: Stacy T.

description: The guy was so unhappy with me and I have no idea why. Because I was asking questions? Only wanted half a chicken? Was not Asian? I have no idea, but the dude was giving off the angry vibe, which he took out on my chicken while chopping it up. And the chicken wasn't even very good.
author: Jason B.

description:
WHAT HAPPENED?

I've been here several times because they are open before 9 am and aside from the one bad experience I had with a flaky pastry product  that had boiled eggs, pork and big pieces of onion cooked with some nasty sauce that made the innards all goopy, I've liked what they had to offer UNTIL today...

Let me just say, I feel oogy *blech*
Har gow - gross, shrimp smelled OLD

Beef sui may - disgusting... large greyish rubber mystery meat balls - boi-yoing

Pan fried shrimp and chive - I think they must've dumped a box of cornstarch  in the mix... could this be the source of the mystery goop in their food?
author: Theresa P.

description: Go to the dim sum side. The curry beef bun is the perfect deep-fried guilty pleasure and no one else on Clement St. sells it.  Their baked pork buns are the real deal--  nice crusty light bun and no shocking pink mystery meat inside, but moist almost caramelized pork. If you're feeling semi-healthy, go for the steamed chicken bun or  the new item, a baked chicken bun-- I don't know about that one, but they are excited about it.
author: Miz J.

description: This place has a huge assortment of dim sum and pastries and other edibles.  Try the thousand year egg old jook with jin dooey ( fried bread) or the green onion steamed rolls for breakfast.   Then on to the famed steamed porkbuns, chicken siu mai, warm hom gocks, and woo gocks (taro).  The wrapped sticky rice is also quite yummy.  Finish it off with a sweet taro roll or don tot ( egg custard).   Spend a few days there and explore.  Drop by during the moon festival or new years and they have baked other special holiday treats.  The staff might seem gruff, but they are actually very friendly and they speak at least four dialects of Chinese and  English/
author: Wilfred L.

description: After sampling different bakeries and bun shops, this place has the best pork buns, pineapple, bbq chicken, ham and egg, etc buns on Clement St.  The buns with fillings are always consistent and not like some places that make them so you're almost hunting for the bbq pork.  It does cost a little bit more (+20 cents) for their baos, but you know where that extra money went.  Their varieties are always great and it has me coming for more.  If they didn't make baos like they do here, I wouldn't even consider having baos for breakfast, even with the immense selection on this stretch of road.  Their dim-sum is not bad, but I do prefer the other place if time permits.
author: Tim L.

description: What an experience this place has always been!  The Bao is a favorite for years!  We have never eaten in the regular place, only done pick up of the pink boxes full of bao tied with string.  When you get to the area there, it is usually full, so you get around it by dropping one person off, then you circle around in the car and pick them back up.  Then you take your TREASURE to a nearby park, and eat them while they are still warm and soft!  YUMMY!  Or... Bring a bunch home and eat them over the next couple of days... but be sure to share, everyone we introduce to this place is now hooked!  They are catching on!
author: Jan C.

description: Don't get me wrong - I like sweet BBQ pork buns.  But here, they are savory and delicious.  The line is quick, the prices are super cheap, and the selection is excellent.  If you are a not embarrassed white girl like me, you might enjoy their American treats seen in the window - hot dog buns and more.  I also enjoy bringing their desserts to parties across the city - another bit of pride of the Richmond!
author: Carrie R.

description: Have been going to this place for years. Since I no longer live in the city, I don't go as much but every time I'm in the area, I try to make time and pick up some dim sum before I head back home. After all of these years, their dim sum has been pretty consistent and I still enjoy their food from the first time my dad took me there.
author: Terance L.

description: I really love the cha siu bao here--the meat is sliced, not shredded, so you know what's inside.  However, whenever I've ventured out and bought anything else, I was pleasantly surprised.  Not to mention, the prices are great.
author: Kelvin K.

description: Despite the attitude of the people that work there I still go there just for the dim sum. Best dim sum ever! And  their other food selections are delicious too!
author: Nancy T.

description: 4.5 Clement Restaurant is probably my favorite dim sum place.  I've tried a couple different places and clement street restaurant as a great assortment at dirt cheap prices.  My favorites are the  pork buns and shrimp dumplings.
author: Sesily M.

description: I went at 2 pm, and the service was not-rude. One the diner side, it's true, you can get two selections, with rice, fried rice, chow mein or fun and the servings are huge! Serious, that container was heavy. They don't skimp! And I love that they use those tightly sealed plastic containers with the snap lids, instead of those white styrofoam containers with the loose floppy lids (lots of spilt gravy in the bag!). On the dim sum side, I got the Chinese donut (I said "one", she sorta sneered and put two in the bag, maybe because there are two per order?), one scallion pancake, one chive dumpling, one baked charsiu bao, and it was like only $3!! This place is a steal, and yes, it's very, very tasty. The combo plate alone is two full dinners.
author: Ice Cream Truck I.

description: Yes, I agree with the 4 star reviews on taste etc, but took away a star, because a few times when I have bought in the early mornings, it seems that some of the steamed dim sum were not as fresh as they should be.
author: Nini L.

description: good luck dimsum was closed - i wanted to try their congee. so my feet took me to Clement Restaurant. first of all, the line was full of my peeps (pellow pilipinos!) which was a good sign! AND they had 3 kinds of congee! and they had the fried bread thingy! oooh! but since i got there late, they only had 2 of the 3 kinds of congee so that was a little sad. and the lady was slightly irritable (maybe because the people ahead of me were kinda dilly dallying). hmmmm congeeeeee was deelirshus and definitely not stingy on the meat side. i would have loved more of the egg though. no matter, the presence of dipping bread made it all worth it. and the sesame ball for dessert was a lovely ending. hooray! another congee hankering conquered!
author: ray e.

description: This place has the BEST pineapple buns! seriously.. hands down. You must try them. The top coat is so good and cannot be found anywhere else. They are a bit pricier than most places but they're totally worth it. Talking about them just makes my mouth watery.. hmm. I usually go out of my way just to get my hands on one of them. Love them especially when they're warm.
author: Dianne I.
